reviewText:
Yes, I would recommend this game. No, it is not perfect, but it is good value and one of the better game experiences I have enjoyed lately. One thing I would say, this is an adventure game masquerading as a platform game. The majority of the gameplay comes from finding items and using them. The graphics and story are superb, but the other aspects of the game let it down somewhat. It is short, but at the same time I enjoyed every second and was happy with it - I've pumped many hours into far less satisfying experiences that have lasted much longer; quality over quantity I say.

The combat is boring. It boils down to going in and out of camoflauge (which can be done anywhere, making the terrain cover system a hinderance as camoflauge is simpler to use) and waiting for the robots to stop shooting before shooting their heads off. They don't move or vary their attacks or ever threaten you from multiple sides or tricky angles. It is almost without skill, never difficult, and even if you do die the last checkpoint is always a few seconds before.

There's actually very few ways to die beyond the security robots, which I think detracts from the game. ARID stops you going into dangerous places when surprise deaths would be a better way to startle the player.

About that platform game thing; there's no sections with urgency or where timing/skill is particularly important - think the flooding scene in Another World or some of the Shadow of the Beast sequences. So whilst the atmosphere of the game harks back to those classics, in terms of gameplay it ends up falling short.

Storyline is where the game excels. The graphics and sound are superb producing a believable environment and great atmosphere, there's never any boring point in The Fall. If there was a criticism about the gameworld, I'd say that sometimes the design is a bit... iffy. You end up running back and forth quite long distances and some of the things you need to do are a bit obscure (hint: ceilings!) so you end up running around searching everywhere and trying all the items in your inventory at each point - a bit like a classic adventure game really.

So, yeah, if you like adventure games this is definitely for you! If you like platform games, well, this isn't really one - it just looks like one.

reviewText:
NOTE: At the time of writing, The Fall is the first episode only - most story arcs are wrapped up but it is too early to tell where the overall plot will go.
The Fall is a story-driven side scrolling adventure with intermingled action sequences. I picked it up in a daily sale and would highly recommend it - it's really strong on building its story and mood through exploration and the plot rapidly drew me in. The game is strongest on the artistic side: level backgrounds are simple but beautiful and effectively convey the desolation of its setting, the voice acting is enjoyable and supports the story themes well, and the story itself kept me interested for the duration of play (about 4 hours). I would say that if the game is one thing, it is coherent: Main menu and GUI, the world it builds and the story all mesh together nicely.

The game's mechanics are a bit more variable in quality. The shooter mechanics are bland 2D-cover based shooting, and I personally found them to be a bit pointless. The puzzles worked reasonably well, and meshed nicely with the exploration aspect of the game which is highly linear but significantly contributes to the game's creepy mood. Unfortunately, the game fails to signpost adequately how far you have to travel to acquire the items you need to solve the puzzles, notably in the game's middle section you have to travel through large areas that are shut down" and point out to you that you should not go there yet
date: but to progress you must travel through them. In fact
recommended: at several points characters specifically tell you that you are in the wrong place and not completing your tasks in the right order... which may be very clever meta-game commentary given the nature of the story

reviewText:
A wonderfully done tale of a robotic suit (think Iron Man) that has crash landed in a strange place and must seek medical treatment for the man assigned to wear it, who is unresponsive. Throughout, we see ARID, the suit's designation, do whatever it takes to accomplish that task... even if it means cheating her core programming. Not that she'd admit to herself that's what she's doing, of course.

The themes of free will and the dark atmosphere are beautifully put together. ARID's interactions with the world around her are both clever and even belying a wry sense of humor now and then. Some of the puzzles can be a bit tricky, but they can usually be worked out with enough tinkering, though I will admit to finding a video on one of the trials. (forgive me)

Overall, I would heartily recommend this game to anyone who is interested in the genre and I eagerly anticipate the next two chapters in the story.

reviewText: I went in to this expecting a short, interesting little sci-fi story. What I did not expect was a series of well thought out and well constructed puzzles with a great sci-fi story and honestly brilliant characters. I love it. The puzzles are fairly complex around the midpoint, but they can be solved with a little bit of lateral thinking. There's a nice bit of backstory if you find enough reading bits, and there are a couple of moments where you have to make a couple of choices (obvious and not) that I'm hoping will matter in the next episode. The combat was admittedly fairly basic, but it had enough variety to not get tedious, especially with the boss of this first episode. It does look like it'll be an episodic game, but maybe I missed that in the store page. In any event, I am very much looking forward to part 2.

reviewText: To be honest, I picked up The Fall on a whim. It looked like a cool side-scroller shooter, and mentioned some puzzles in the description. I was DEFINITELY not prepared for how good it actually is. The Fall is immersive from the start, and, unless you get stuck on some of the puzzles, maintains the immersion the whole way through. With a driving mysterious plot, some insanely dark and awesome characters, and easily navigated controls, The Fall is one of the better games offered in the Steam Sale so far.\n\nYou play the AI Co-Pilot of a combat mech suit, and your human pilot has suffered injuries. It's a wonderful mashup of old-school side scrollers with some incredibly brilliant puzzle design work. I even found myself laughing out loud at some of the darker subtle comedy. DEFINITELY worth the 5 bucks.

reviewText:
As the AI of a suit of powered armour, you are bound by your robotic laws to safeguard the human inside you, even if they're unconscious and you have to keep stretching the letter of the law to activate more of your abilities to keep him safe.

A fantasticaly atmospheric platformer, with art that's just to die for, light on characters but each is given more depth than you'd expect. Absolutely emotionally gutting in parts and the puzzles are never too fiendish that you'll slam your head against the wall in frustration.

Check it out if you dig strong female protagonists too. That's me assuming gender though, based mostly on the stellar voice work from all involved.

reviewText:
One word comes to mind when I think back on this game, WOW.
I was blown away by this game that I purchased on a whim. The story is thoughtfully crafted and overcomes the pitfalls that plague many games' stories.  The characters within are well written and believable (not many games can say that anymore).  I am genuinely excited to find out what happens in the next chapters of the game.
My only complaints is one that many games of it's genre suffer from.  It boils down to plugging the right item into the right slot in the right order.  This can be a bit frustrating at times, especially when some “slots” are not made clear.
I feel guilty about buying the game on sale, I will definantly be buying the next chapter at full price.

reviewText:
This game has some of the best storytelling I've ever seen in gaming.  For once, you're not playing the badass who guns his way through a horde of enemies, you're playing the suit that has to save his sorry ♥♥♥ when he's taken too much damage.  The characters- despite being robots- are all fascinating, with personalities more fleshed out than many human characters in gaming.  The voice acting is top notch.  The actions that you perform in puzzles actually tie in nicely with the overall theme of story, which is to push the boundaries of your protocol as an A.I.  The atmosphere is beautiful and foreboding, which adds to the sense of urgency to protect A.R.I.D's pilot and find him medical treatment as soon as possible.  As some one who values great stories, an immersive atmosphere, and excellent dialogue, I could not recommend this game more.

However... the game mechanics could use some work.  The controls are not intuitive, and the main character is difficult to maneuver at times.  For example, I chose to toggle my weapon, and A.R.I.D. kept putting away her gun every time she jumped.  This made one particular battle towards the end incredibly frustrating, since I would jump to avoid attacks, and then have to pull out my gun again before trying to get in a few shots while the enemy was vulnerable.  Performing actions on objects requires holding down shift and then choosing from a list of options; it would have been much easier to just be able to shine the flashlight onto an object and have the options automatically show up underneath.  In a four hour game, I really don't want to spend half my time getting use to controls. I want to be able to pick up the game mechanics very quickly and spend the rest of my time immersed in a complex, clever, and compelling story.

I never write reviews, but The Fall" is such a good game
date: and it deserves a lot more attention than it's received so far.  I cannot wait to play the next episode and follow A.R.I.D. in her rebellion against protocol."

reviewText:
What a fantastic little gem this was!

A fairly simple meshing of Another World's sidescrolling action gameplay fused with classic point and click mechanics.  What really elevates the package here is the combined setting and story.  A very unique and unsettling take on robotics and the programmed rules they are forced to abide.  For a such a dark place void of life, there is a TON of character in this game.  10/10.

Fingers crossed on that promise of more time in this world.

reviewText: The Fall won Giant Bomb's best story award, and it's well earned! The Fall is about a robot suit that crashes into a decaying robot decommissioning plant. The suit is controlled by an AI (the player character) whose primary directive is to keep the unconscious pilot safe. However, the suit won't give the AI free reign until it encounters situations that put the pilot at risk. The gameplay is a mix of puzzle solving and some light action. The puzzle solving comes from trying to get into situations in which the suit is threatened in a way that unlocks a new ability, such as getting shot at so that you can unlock the cloak and sneak past. It's often pretty clever.\n\nBut it didn't win the best story award for having interesting puzzles. The writing in The Fall is pretty fantastic. I won't discuss it in detail, but you will quickly learn that you're not alone in the derelict facility. It's an episodic game, and this is just the first episode. It ends with a pretty big cliffhanger, so I'm hoping we don't have to wait long for the rest.

reviewText:
I picked this game up yesterday and played through it today, so I am in no way associated with the Kickstarter campaign like many of the previous writers are. This dosn't meen that I accuse them of being biased, though, because I share their opinion.

The Fall is a surprising hit, the atmosphere, a combining of The Swapper, Dead Space and a bit of The Cat Lady, is gritty, dark and super tense. Furthermore, the protagonist is a real blast. I am fond of nearly all AI in video games - GlaDOS and ED-E are among my most beloved characters of all time - and A.R.I.D is by far the best carved out AI I ever saw in  a video game. Or a movie. Yes, better than GlaDOS and HAL. Her developing is great, her actions are exactly how I would think a programmed AI should react, and her voice is lovable.
Not to mention the story. Every word said would be a blasphemous spoiler, but let me say that I was really amazed at the end and I will gladly await the next episodes. Yes, I should explicitely stress that this is an episodic game, with only the first part being out now. I just hope the rest won't take long.

One negative point at the end, though: The fighting is really frustrating sometimes. The mouse controls are certainly not the best, and since enemies will only take real damage when shooting their head, it can kill you a few times to try and aim correctly with your gun flinging wildly over the screen. Minor setback though, fighting is only a little part of the gameplay.

reviewText:
Wow, where to start. I have never played a puzzler like this before. It's a short game, and for it's length, full price is a bit much in my opinion. But honestly this game blew me away. It was unique, and had me thinking out of the box. Whenever I got stuck on certain obstacles I would realize that I kept searching for something specific. Once I let go of that idea and stopped, I started solving the puzzles faster because this game requires you to solve the problems in an unorthodox way. The story was unexpected and an unimportant side info (not critical story details) isn't directly told to you, but discovered on your own which I like more because it gets me more engaged in the game.

For a emotionless AI, I became attached to A.R.I.D's character. Her humor is dry, and unintentional, and I really enjoyed her character development throughtout the story. It doesn't make any sense, but once you start playing you will understand what I'm talking about.

But let's be honest, if this were Siri in that combat suit, that pilot is as good as dead.

I give this game 5 iPhones/ 5

reviewText:
I backed this game in Kickstarter because of the atmosphere and because it seemed clever somehow.
I wasn't disappointed. The atmosphere is brilliant, the plot intriguing and the gameplay is a good mixture between point and click, a little of action and a special touch of character leveling up.
It reminds me of The Cat Lady (whic is good). This is just the first chapter, but Arid seems to be one of this characters that stick.
There is a few small bugs, the controls could be a little better (using Xbox controller), but all in all the game is a pleasure to play.
Waiting eagerly for the next chapters.

reviewText:
[NO SPOILERS]

Wow. Just wow.

Immersive visuals, tense and dark story, well-written dialog, puzzles that are the right kind of tough, horror focused on making you feel uncomfortable and lost rather than jumpscares and cliches.

There are two cons however:
- The difficulty of the puzzles can vary. I found two to be impossible, so I had to look them up, but the others were relatively easy to tough but rewarding. Most puzzles were satisfying, however.
- The combat feels a little bit clunky at times (due to the control mechanics), but it doesn't distract from the rest of the gameplay for me. I actually think it's nice, because it changes the pace now and then to keep you interested.

I had to finish the game in one week. The story is just so good, I was constantly wondering what would happen next, and it constantly surprised me in a good way. A unique game that I can't recommend enough.


Can't wait for the sequel, I want to see more of this for sure!

reviewText:
Go play this game NOW! Support the developers! Because I want a sequel!

Ok ok ok, I'm getting ahead of myself. Let me explain why you need to buy this game.
Pros: STORY!!! This is what makes the game stand out. It has an incredibly good story with great, interesting characters. This is what makes it worth playing. Since it's a game and not a movie/comic/whatever YOU are the one making choices, and that is what makes stories in games so immersive.
and for the record: the graphics, music and atmosphere are great and really fitting to the theme. The voice-acting is superb and the dialogue is well-written.
Did I mention that the story is great?

OK, fine. Here are some cons, but they are insignificant next to the amazing story.
Cons: Combat feels a little awkward. It's basically the same combat as Blizzard's Blackthorne from way back in the day. Sure, it feels kinda strategic but it also feels kinda dated to me. And towards the end i felt the cover system bugging.
The UI in's great. it took me a while to figure out how to interact with things and even then the interaction menu felt awkward.
linear story. You cant alter it, as far as I know. The developers want to convey their story and they're not letting stupid players like us mess with it.
Minor bugs and glitches. like the tutorial texts overlapping in the corner. I was unable to exit the options menu after editing key bindings. And melee killing an enemy behind cover several feet away.

MINOR SPOILER: There is a scene where it makes you think you have a choice, for emotional reasons, but you don't. Not as a player. The story demands that you do this, and it does fit your character that you do it, and your character DOES/WOULD make the choice, but it feels more emotional that you have to do it and not just watch a cutscene. So it's most definitely on purpose. I am unsure if this is actually a con or just brilliant writing.

So in conclusion: BUY THIS GAME!!!

reviewText:
Take a walk in the shoes of an AI.
Most science fiction fans are well versed in media treatments of emergent artificial intelligence, whether movies, books or games.  The Fall by recent indie developer Over The Moon via Kickstarter is one of the more entertaining treatments that I've come across, & it also blends genres like only indie titles can.

The game is part point & click adventure puzzler, part side scrolling action.  I like how story and gameplay inform each other.  I like the considerations that the devs present concerning how an AI might behave if it detected inconsistencies or imperfections in programming/protocols.

The puzzles are manageable with thorough searching and a bit of thought.  Only in a couple of instances was I stumped for a while.  The exploration, item interaction, combat & cover worked well enough & were free of hassle.  Visuals & audio were acceptable for a low budget indie.  I have mixed feelings the AI voice acting, but overall it's well done.

The game really is brief, only four to five hours for a playthrough.  Very much looking forward to the sequel.  I highly recommend The Fall to any player with interest in science fiction and/or a desire to have their brain tickled for a bit.  It just requires a bit of time & patience, like any point & click puzzler.

reviewText: A short, interesting game, The Fall's strength lies in its narrative following the A.I. of a suit of armour trying to save its human pilot through a dark and twisted setting. There are some occasionally frustrating control issues, but largely The Fall plays like a contemporary point & click adventure like The Silent Age or Gemini Rue. Add in some gorgeously dark and understated graphics and there's more than enough to hold one's attention. The price may be a tad high for what you're getting (I completed the game in a single sitting one evening) but for the £2 I spent, I'm a very satisfied customer.

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to face off against mutant slugs, psycho robots and deadly fish with teeth like razors? Then this might be the game for you

Step into the role of ARID, an AI controlled combat suit who will do anything to save her pilot from impending doom whilst traversing the hellscape of an abandoned robotics factory. She finds friends and foe upon her journey to salvation, a journey that will make her question every rule governing her existence as a machine.

ARID is a pretty awesome character, she grows throughout the whole game from being so subservient in the beginning to questioning her reality and how she has to break the rules to save her pilot. For a machine she is very complex and I felt compelled to see how this story ends. The few other characters you meet are very interesting in their own right; I get a real feeling that each has their own story that would be equally interesting to see how they got to where they are today.

The world in which the game is set, although not large by any stretch of the imagination, is full of things that are interesting and show depth not explored in the game. Finding a few notes here and there giving you details but not the whole picture as to what happened in this place and how it became so decayed and forgotten. It had a decrepit beauty to it that I enjoyed to no end. The story appears simple from the outside but is, I suspect, a metaphor for something much deeper. I had a great time from start to end.

The game plays well for a platformer, the gun controls are clunky and the menu selections aren’t the best. But neither hampers the enjoyment and both add to the charm of this indie gem. The game is full of puzzles and challenges, none of which were too difficult to overcome and gave a great sense of accomplishment when you figured out how to beat them. The sound is great too, the voices are fantastic and really add to the characters, the music is ominous and foreboding and the ambient noises brought some life to the dead world.

I thoroughly enjoyed this game from start to finish, so much so that I have played it through twice now and still had a blast. If this is on sale it is a must buy, at full price you would still get a lot of enjoyment out of it but with the short length you might want to wait. So everyone out there help ARID out and play this game.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
First the bad. To put it frankly and concisely, the controls/interface are not user friendly AT ALL. You will struggle against them for the entire game.

However, if you begrudgingly accept the controls/interface for what they are, you will be blessed with a wonderful adventure game in the most classic sense of the word (including the part where you wander around for 45 minutes using the fork on the light switch for the seventh time because you don't know what to do next, and I mean that in the best way).

Also the game has a really great story. The basic premise is that a futuristic combat suit equipped with an AI has essentially gone into emergency auto-pilot in order to help the dying person within the suit. (Yes, you read that right. In this story, you play the role of sentient clothing!) What follows is yet another tale that closely examines the point at which intelligence ceases to be artificial intelligence and becomes just regular intelligence.

OH WAIT. Did I mention that you will also be blessed with BLACKTHORNE STYLE COMBAT.

BLACKTHOOOOOOOOOORNE.

Overall this game was pretty sweet, but now I have to go play Blackthorne.

VERDICT:

7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.
6) A good game that is worth the full price.5) A pretty good game worth checking out--especially if discounted.
4) A fairly good game, but I'd recommend buying it discounted.
3) Not great, but a few redeeming qualities. Only buy if heavily discounted.
2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.
1) Avoid at all costs.

reviewText:
I strongly recommend this game, especially if it's on sale and you happen to be looking at the reviews wondering if it's worth spending a few bucks on.

This is one of the very few games I have ever played where the story alone kept me interested.  Excellently written, well voiced, tightly focused, and thought provoking.  Science fiction done as well as a good book or movie.

The gameplay is decent, but nothing spectacular.  It's about a 60/30/10 mix of exploration, puzzle solving, and action.  The exploration ties in very well with the story, but the combat will probably disappoint people who are looking for something more challenging.  As for the puzzles, I'll give them props for making sure the in-game logs give the player clues how to solve them, but it's still your basic adventure game logic of run around rubbing things on other things to see what works."  Whether you consider that a draw or a drawback will depend on how you feel about adventure games.

My only complaint would be the length.  It's a short game

reviewText:
Fans of adventure games will enjoy The Fall.

Setting: Set in the future on a different planet, an installation that has fallen into extreme disrepair.

Game mechanics:
The game is a sidescroller, moving the character feels solid. The camera stretches ahead of the player to show them what's coming, but sometimes feels a bit wonky when changing directions rapidly. The action doesn't require this though, so it doesn't impede gameplay. Players use their flashlight to highlight items of interest, and then can hold left shift to select actions or inventory items to interact. This feels natural after a short time and fits the adventure genre perfectly.

The puzzles are varied and some took time to figure out. The player has to keep a constant lookout for objects of interest.

The game has combat. The cover system feels a little loose. The command to enter cover has a sweet spot close behind the object. This created moments where I felt I was battling positioning my character more than the opposition. Enemies hang out of cover a little too long, making gun battles a little too easy.

Conclusion: Despite minor issues, I had a great time with The Fall. The plot and puzzle solving is engaging enough players will want to see the game through to the end. The developers have stated this will be a series. I'm excited for the next installment.

reviewText:
I honestly don't understand all the lavish praise being heaped on this game.

It's a point anc click advernture with a few very easy shooting bits. I was expecting so much more... something akin to Shadowrun meets an old Lucasarts adventure. Sadly, it's not close to either. Its' not exactly bad, it's just not as good as the hype by a long shot.

As a point and click adventure goes, it's messy. Many of the puzzles are akin to doing a jigsaw puzzle where all the pieces are the same colour... except someone put all the jigsaw pieces in different rooms of your house to make you run backwards and forwards to annoy you. If you take out all the wandering around the actual game time is proably not much more than a 1-2 hours.

The combat is purely textural. It's not challenging whatsover. The character animation is very basic (eg; you jump in the air but as your character lands it crudely cuts to a different standing postiton). Anything worth of a 'game of the year' review surely desrves attention to detail with the basics.

As for the story, fairly well written but unfinished as yet given it's a trilogy. If the other two parts were just updates to this game I'd maybe tempted to give this a positive review, but as it stands this just feels like an unfinished untuned game with far too many rough edges.

5.5/10

reviewText:
The Good:
- The voice actor who played the system administrator did a phenomenal job.

- Unquestionably, the best parts of this game are the interactions between the ARID and the System Administrator. Their dialogue throughout the game kept me invested and became the only reason I played through to the end.

The Bad:
- As stated, the interactions between ARID and the System Administrator were the best parts of the game. However, the resolution to their story came too abruptly. This gripe was not helped by the unsatisfying conclusion to the game.

- The combat segments did not add anything to the game. In fact, these parts felt like they were just there to extend the length of the game.

- Some of the character animations are really rough. For example, when the main character jumps the transition from the jump position to the standing position is jarring. Moreover, the sluggish controls further expose the rough animations.

- I experienced some bugs during my playthrough which forced me to close out the game and restart.

Final Verdict:
There are some great aspects to this game, but it’s marred by elements which provide no value to the gameplay or story. As a result, I can’t recommend this game. Perhaps, when the story arch is complete it might be worth playing through, but in its current state it’s not worth it. As an aside, the name of this game is too generic and it’s difficult to look up information regarding the second game because of it. At the very least they could have titled it The Fall: I Don’t Know, Something Clever.

reviewText:
While The Fall does throw occassional moments of combat at you, you'll spend the majority of the game exploring the environment looking for any item or clue that may help you solve problems (I can't quite bring myself to call them puzzles) in order to progress.

The game is dark, which not only adds to the creepy atmosphere, but forces you to inspect every inch of the game with your flashlight to ensure you haven't missed something (I'll also note that the only way to interact with your environment is to first aim your flashlight onto an object, so you literally can't play the game without constantly shining your flashlight onto everything anyway). Some might find this annoying, I didn't mind the mechanic personally, and once I got used to the awkward controls I found myself very immersed in the gameplay.

Combat is fairly simple, take cover (or cloak) until enemies pause between firing at you, then lean out (or uncloak) and try to pop them in the head for maximum damage. You can also perform stealth takedowns, though they require little effort, and tougher enemies are introduced as you progress, which adds just enough to keep combat from feeling like work but doesn't add enough to consider the combat deep or particularly interesting. Luckily, as I already mentioned, the combat is occassional in this game, so it never really has enough time to make you feel bored or annoyed by it.

The Fall is a small game, and by small I mean there are only a handful of areas in the game that you'll explore and none of them could be considered large. HOWEVER, the nature of the game will have you spending a lot of time in each of these areas rather than just moving through them once or twice. Progression will require you to seek out and find items that you can utilize to solve problems, and sometimes an item you find early on won't be needed until late in the game, or an item you find late in the game needs to be used in an earlier area. There's a lot of backtracking, so if that's something you dislike in games, this isn't for you.

The game world in The Fall is mysterious and interesting. You're kept out of the loop for most of the game, learning bits and pieces about what's going on through conversations or finding messages. The characters are well done and each have a unique personallity from one another. Some of the dialogue and voice acting could've been better in places, but by no means do I consider any of it to be bad. I really enjoyed the atmosphere of the game, and I think a great job was done in putting it all together.

Overall, The Fall is simple in design, but delivers challenging content (I admit I needed to refer to a guide a few times because I was totally stumped). The visuals are creepy, the music is creepy, the characters are creepy, and I loved it. At $9.99 its definitely worth it if you like exploration and problem solving, and if you manage to grab it on sale then its an absolute must play. At around 3-4 hours long, I'm confident you'll be satisfied (and apparently a sequel is in the works, so there will be even more The Fall to come in the future. I look forward to it).

reviewText:
First things first. This isnt a full game, it's simply Episode 1, bear that in mind before committing to any purchase.

The Fall is side scrolling adventure game in the vein of Broken Age and Monkey Island, except that it's plot is deep sci-fi and it's atmosphere evokes the kind of slow burning space-terror found in 2001 A Space Oddysey.

I liked the atmosphere honestly, but i found the controls clunky, the puzzles solved by dumb luck more often that skill and while I can see what the developer really wanted out of the combat, it doesnt really deliver.

Maybe future versions and updates of The Fall will help deal with the gripes I've had so far, but who can say.

reviewText:
The Fall é um adventure sci-fi incrível, criminalmente sub-apreciado (e também pouquíssimo conhecido) pela mídia e pelos jogadores.O jogo é um adventure, mas funciona como um sidescroller. Você se move/pula como em um jogo tradicional do gênero e interage com o cenário iluminando locais que sejam do seu interesse, podendo olhar, tocar, etc. A trama gira em torno de ARID, uma I.A que é ativada assim que seu hospedeiro estiver em risco de vida e inconsciente.   Tudo começa com uma queda (The Fall) em um planeta desconhecido. ARID é ativada no decorrer disso e, ao perceber que o humano está desacordado além de ferido, tenta encontrar um centro médico.

Logo no iníco, fica evidente a eficiência do enredo. ARID diz que está procurando atendimento médico para salvar a vida de seu hospedeiro, mas suas ações constantemente contradizem isso. Diversas vezes ela bota em risco a vida do humano para sobrepor protocolos, e assim, poder avançar no local em que ela se encontra. Tecnicamente, isso é necessário para alcançar o centro médico, mas a moralidade de suas ações é dubiosa e deixa o jogador se questionando se a I.A está funcionando de forma correta e se realmente está com o bem estar do hospedeiro em mente. Dentro do contexto bizarro e um pouco assustador do jogo, tudo isso fica crível. A ambientação corrobora com isso, com um aspecto desolado. Pequenos montes de robôs que foram descartados estão espalhados pela estação, pessoas crucificadas são encontradas, tudo isso se incrementa a sensação de algo errado estar acontecendo.  Os dialógos são excelentes, escritos com maestria, cada personagem é bem desenvolvido e tem relevância no desenrolar da história, e a qualidade deles é exaltada pelo voice acting.

Isso foi o que mais me surpreendeu, é simplesmente sublime. Cada personagem é representado com maestria. ARID, por exemplo, com sua frieza e determinação de atingir seu objetivo, sem se preocupar com as consequências. Apesar de não ser o destaque, sua atriz fez um ótimo trabalho. E o mesmo pode ser dito para os coadjuvantes. (Um, em especial, foi o destaque do jogo, mas prefiro que joguem e descubram)

Os controles, entretanto, são um pouco falhos. O personagem é um pouco ‘floaty’, o jogo tem combate, que é, basicamente, entrar em cobertura com um botão e esperar os inimigos pararem de atirar, contra-atacando, mas a mira do personagem nem sempre é precisa como o desejado. Isso atrapalha em alguns combates, especialmente na parte final do jogo, e em algumas conquistas (para quem se importa com isso). De qualquer forma, achei essa mecânica uma boa distração dos puzzles, algo que dá uma gratificação imediata.

A estrutura dos puzzles é ótima. Todos eles tem ligação a narrativa do jogo, e não foram pensados apenas como um obstáculo ao jogador. Alguns deles são brutais, com back-tracking, exploração de diversas salas e pensamentos criativos para a solução. Diria até que um deles é obscuro demais, com um back-tracking que, em certo momento, fica chato e obtuso. Soluções lógicas são substituidas por algo mais enigmático a favor de dificultar a vida do jogador, e, talvez, aumentar a longevidade do jogo. Entretanto, senti isso em apenas um deles. Geralmente, necessitam de exploração atenciosa aos arredores e um pensamento fora da caixa" nas soluções.

The Fall começou com um primeiro episódio extraordinário
date: que não recorre a nenhum clichê
recommended: contando com um final extremamente satisfatório (o que
voteText: é algo incomum para jogos). Infelizmente
helpfulPercent: ele recebeu pouquíssimo destaque da mídia e uma atenção ainda menor dos jogadores. Recomendo a qualquer um que gosta de adventures e ficção científica.\n"

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings.

It's a generelly nicely immersive game with some great voice acting, interesting characters and clever writing that begs for a continuation as the game ends with a cliffhanger.

You control a robot suit that is supposed to be piloted by a human person wearing it. From space you violently crash into some planet's surface diving some dozen meters below into a cavern. With the human operator unresponsive and possibly seriously injured the robot suit's A.I. takes control of all movements attempting to reach the surface where it hopes to find medical aid for the pilot. Along the way the A.I. intentionally puts the pilot at even greater risks to gain access to otherwise unauthorized systems of the suit, fighting off other robots that don't take too kindly to her presence (or, at least your A.I. is voiced pretty greatly by a woman), solving puzzles, discovering a bit about the domestic robot production facility she'll soon stumble into and even more about herself raising philosophical questions for example about humankind, artifical intelligence, obedience and empathy.

The gameplay can be a bit tedious. What may look like an action platformer at first sight is for most parts actually a sidescrolling, puzzle-solving adventure game. There is combat, but it feels tacked on and as similarily stiff as it did to me in Gemini Rue". The game could easily live without it
date: though a gun with an attached flashlight that is aimed down in the eerie dark to examine things probably begs to be fired.\n\nThe middle part where you are supposed to do what felt like petty errands in order to "graduate" as a "domestic robot" in that abandoned facility didn't feel as enjoyable
recommended: though I suppose oldschool adventure fans will love the dozen item-world-interactions and backtracking you'll have to do (I did look up a walkthrough because I got stuck several times and wanted to speed it up). Story-wise I guess these parts fit
hoursPlayed: but the general philosophical message that comes with them probably could have been expressed just as well without dragging on for as long.\nBut perhaps I'm biased. I almost naturally prefer less puzzling/adventuring and more of an interactive/cinematic experience when it comes to games that are as immersive as this one as I like to stay "in flow". Here you'll inevitably stumble a bit unless you are a puzzling pro or have a walkthrough/a Steam guide at your side. I don't remember the puzzles as being illogical but things are rarely plain obvious either. No handholding here
voteText: Telltale friends.\n\nIt's a genuinely interesting title that feels somewhat bold and ambitious
helpfulPercent: but I'm not entirely sure if it wants to or should be a puzzle-solving adventure game or a more direct/cinematic action title."

reviewText:
The mouse and keyboard controls for this game are atrocious.

This is the heart of what is killing the game for me.

It's like playing an old school point-n-click adventure game except I need to constantly hold the mouse button, wiggle the mouse at key items in the game, and figure out the puzzles at the same time. “Frustrating” doesn't begin to describe the feeling this scheme evokes.  What? I can't collect blood in a pan until a dialog trigger? I haven't had to put up with that since I played “I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream”. Yes, that's the sound of 1995 calling. They want their linear plot mechanics back.

I admit, I could sit and work my way through following a  Youtube walkthrough but this defeats the purpose of me playing the game. Mind you, all of this complaining this is coming from someone who revels in the difficulty of “Dark Souls” and the complexity of the “ARMA” series or “Crusader Kings II”. I just don't care enough to put up with this in this particular game.

Ranting out of the way, I don't want to sound mean because it sounds like people are really getting something from this. Looking at the other reviews, it looks like this game may offer something exciting. The plot may be wonderful, but I simply don't have the patience nor the attachment with the game to get very far. I don't find the game's atmosphere to be particularly novel (see Limbo" or "The Swapper") and the voice acting may or may not be the best thing ever
date:
but these certainly aren't enough to cover for this game's blinding flaw.

Get it on sale with low expectations. I hope it works for you.

Me?

I might come around to try this again when the game is polished or if the plot grabs me in some fantastic way when future episodes come out. I'll be sure  to update this review then."

reviewText: Combat system could use some work.

Simply put: Excellence.

It's a point -n- click adventure with inventory puzzles and action segments which reminded me of Another World ( Out of this World ).

Atmospheric, logical puzzles, and excellent story all add up to an amazing first part of this episodic adventure.  Looking forward to chapter 2.

The Fall has everything anyone needs in life: spooky urban exploration, existential robots, and some pretty sweet glowing environments.

TLDR; pretty graphics, intuitive puzzles, KILLER story, very atmospheric. I highly recommend this game, as it's one of my favorites.

I encountered The Fall earlier in the year and picked it up on sale, as you'll often find it in the steam store, and though I'm not always one for puzzle platformed the lead character had me hooked right away. You play as A.R.I.D., an AI built into a military combat suit, as it navigates a strange planet to save its unconscious human occupant. Even as A.R.I.D. is confined to directive coding any willful human would find ludicrous and hampering, the AI shows itself to an incredibly intelligent, motivated, and even compassionate being. The story itself forces you to make some pretty tough decisions in order to progress; I began the game thinking that A.R.I.D. was a cold and callous thing for making these choices, but by the end I felt I was the one responsible for what it did, and while there's no way around these decisions I felt a lot of remorse for what I was doing; even as a scroller, The Fall is an incredibly immersive experience, and by the end I was so caught up in A.R.I.D.'s story that the cliffhanger finish left me two parts infuriated and four hundred parts distressed for the AI's fate.

There are a few things worth mentioning in regards to the game's mechanics; my most prevalent concern, and that of others I know to have played the game, is that the controls are a little wonky and sometimes the trial/error stage of inventory usage became a little tedious for the key combinations, and you can't access A.R.I.D.'s items with a mouse. Beyond that the controls are well explained and pretty straightforward, and movement/combat is really smooth, and to add to that I think a lot of love was put into the game's graphics. You begin the game in a dark cave filled with fireflies and derelict robotics; lights activate in dead android eyes as you pass, and in the distance a faint humanoid follows your progress. As A.R.I.D. moves from the cave to a droid facility you get to explore run down buildings, most shadowy and rotting. It's a really eerie place at times, and the game's atmosphere is ♥♥♥♥ing spooky in parts, which really forwards the story's growing sense of dread imo. It's a pretty game, in all, with lovely environments and clean character animation.

It's also worth mentioning that this game was made by a really small indie company, and John Warner (the director: his steam username is hypnoslave) is really sweet and very active in the steam forums. The Fall is one of my absolute favorites, hands down, and I'd really love to see Over The Moon supported as they go about making the second and much awaited installment.

Very pleasantly surprised by this one, I can unequivocally recommend it.  Its description gives a mash of genres and of those referenced, 'puzzle-solving adventure game' is by far the strongest.

It looks like a side-scrolling platformer/shooter, but those elements are very light, effectively serving as another type of puzzle.  The strength of this game is in its creepy, slowly-unraveled narrative and gorgeous art.
(Speaking of the art: The screenshots don't do it justice, you have to see it in motion, watch a video - I'm usually skeptical of black-and-white palette silhouette sidescrollers as a cheap-♥♥♥ cop-out to doing REAL art, but there's enough here to make it worth it; it really works.)

The world-building and aesthetic really sell the universe you're dropped into, it all makes a dreadful kind of sense.  My only complaint is that it's too short, and that's not a terrible complaints list to have for five bucks.  Frankly, if there's a sequel/prequel/same-universe game made by these guys in a similar vein, I'll probably snap it up on day one, full price.
More quest, than side scrolling shooter, only one place to jump from platform to platform. Story is realy fascinating,
Good game. But too short.\nAnd don't believe that Fall have FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT"."

Mostly point-and-click mechanics with simple shooting. Excellent story and voice work. Controller support is alright but the default controls take a little while to get accustomed to. Fantastic aesthetic sense.\n\nAnd there's gonna be more! Definitely grab this if you enjoy banter between AI.

This game is seriously something. You immediately fall in love with the main protagonist - Arid, the AI of the mark-7 combat suit awaken to protect its unconscious pilot. Driven by protocols and utilizing loopholes to unlock otherwise unavailable skills she does everything to save Colonel Josephs' life. Will she succeed, depends on you.

Apart from the way the game feels, which is awesome, not so rare issue occurs when switching rapidly between movement modes, i.e. walking (while pointing a side arm), hiding (during shoot-outs) or using a cloaking subsystem. Arid can get stuck behind a cover or display inability to jump, hide again or even run properly after vaulting over an obstacle and killing an enemy droid. Its minor since action isn't the mine focus of the game but still, this kind of bugs never reflect well on a title, especially version 1.43 where all of the movement bugs should be long gone. That and a way less often observed lack of enemy's dying animation are the only technical issues I encountered during the whole gameplay.

Above said, I strongly recommend this title and can't wait for the next episode.

The dark atmosphere, and art direction make this a great game, along with some brilliant writing. Unfortunatley stopping this game from being truly great is the combat, which feels clunky and repetetive, however the game is saved by these sequences being relatively sparse.

It's puzzles are brilliantly designed, if a little bit obtuse, however this was rarely a problem.

Overall the game is held down by it's combat and incredibly short length, and I was left wondering if maybe it wouldn't have been a better use of time creating a longer episode rather than releasing it in it's current length. However, it's puzzles, acting, design and incredible writing make this game a definite must play.

Your goal: Seek Medical Attention.
Your Laws:
1. Don't Misrepresent Reality.
2. Be Obedient.
3. Protect your Operator.
How far are you willing to go?

This game if phenominal; if Isaac Asimov made an Adventure game this is what it would look like.. If you miss Adventure games and want to see what they would look like modernized you need look no further.

Good story, atmosphere, voices.

Puzzles might get frustrating if you don't know what to do or find what you need to advance.


All in all, its a good game that is part 1 of 3, that is kinda short, so it's a little pricey for it's length.
(the time i played on record is exaggerated because i watched some tv while the game was running also played 2 times to get all achievements, to see if story diverge anywhere but there only one real choice that doesn't change anything at least on this game might on the 2º or 3º and got stuck 3 times on 1º playthrough)
Recommend getting this on sale or any price between 5-7€ or waiting till the 3 games are out to get them all, i got mine on Humble Weekley Bundle.

The Fall is a truly atmospheric sci-fi puzzle adventure game.

What happens when an AI withholds the most cherished capacity of human agents, to exercise control over their actions, their lives and ultimately, themselves?

Short, but very atmospheric game. The story is interesting and the combination of action with puzzle solving elements via an inventory is a great little twist on the gameplay elements. I can see myself replaying this in future and look forward to more if it's coming.
This is a great little point n'click style adventure game that can be pretty damn hard in places.\nI enjoyed the plot and with the cheapo sale prices, it's definately worth it!

A very cool adventure game that might look like metroidvania from some perspective but isn't. The interface and controls are rather odd and a bit clunky, but besides slightly increased learning curve its not a problem. You will want to play this game mostly for the story, the gameplay is not particularly great itself. Biggest gripe is the back and forth running you do and you better be very attentive to details to progress... and maybe the shortness and linearity of the game, but linearity is from story focus and shortness from lack of stupid padding most longer games have as excuse for it.

I really enjoyed this game, but it is much too short.  I do not mean that it is too short with respect to the price, but rather that it is too short in absolute terms.\n\nI am going to recommend you buy it, because I am satisfied with the quality, however I assure you that you will be disappointed with the length of the game.

Clocking in at about 3-4 hours, The Fall is on the short side, but manages to be engaging, atmospheric, and tell a compelling story through its dialogue and gameplay. The designers do a good job of building suspense and keeping the player guessing. The puzzles are mostly reasonable; they do a good job of challenging the player without being too obtuse. The Fall is a solid indie game for anybody who's looking for strong narratives and dark atmosphere.
Good Story, Good puzzles, Good Atmosphere.\n\nControls are terrible on the keyboard and mouse so I'd reccomend using a Controller.

What happens when Cortana has to make her way through Aperture Science Laboratories to save Master Chief.

An unreliable narrator? Check.
Moody, atmospheric gameplay? Check.
Relatively tight-enough gunplay? Check.
Chilling narrative and actions? Check.

In short, I recommend this, even if playing with a controller it's a bit flaky manipulating world actions (Why is cancel the default action, requiring me to navigate away every time?)

An awesome atmosphere and intruiging storyline. The puzzles were a little challenging so you do need to use your brain.
It's a little finicky, but the atmosphere, story, and puzzles drive the whole experience. Recommended if you dig atmospheric games and don't mind scratching your head once in a while.

I really enjoyed this game. It's kind of side-scroller, point and click adventure game with multiple puzzles and some combat scenes. It's very atmospheric and the sound is perfect. The story line is very compelling and has an ending that leaves you wanting to play the next episode. Voice acting was good, but I did experience a few glitches while playing. The puzzles were of decent difficulty, not too easy, but not too hard, as long as you keep trying. The combat parts, however, took a while to get down and could be irritating. The controls could be confusing also, and took a while to get used to. It's a pretty short game, since it only took me about 4 hours to complete, but it is part of a trilogy, so you can expect more soon. The main character is A.R.I.D., the AI of a combat suit, who takes over when her pilot lands in the depths of a mysterious facility. She needs find medical treatment for her unconscious pilot and must overcome environmental obstacles, as well as her own restrictive programming.

I would recommend this game, but with a lot of aprehension. The twists are kind of obvious, either because you're expecting them, or because you've read any science fiction novel which discusses AI in any capacity. Puzzles" can usually be solved by doing the standard adventure game
recommended: and then rub everything on everything
hoursPlayed:
but here it feels actually fairly relevant to the story. Repeated attempt at actions without necessarily understanding of why actually fits with the story, as you are essentially an aspect of a computer.

In fact, the reason I would recommend this game to begin with is that it very much gives me the experience of being an AI, at least in some regard. The somewhat awkward controls are obviously more atmospheric, and while the animation for jumping is a little less realistic, it lends itself to the more artificial nature of your entire being. The major complaint I have is partially that it starts in medias res, and oddly I think a lot of information that could be stated about this isn't given. For a game relying on the execution of the story, it does a good job at least in that regard, but it doesn't particularly scratch a deeper universe itch--at least in this stage.

Additionally, if you don't like To Be Continued"s

reviewText:
The dark atmosphere, and art direction make this a great game, along with some brilliant writing. Unfortunatley stopping this game from being truly great is the combat, which feels clunky and repetetive, however the game is saved by these sequences being relatively sparse.

It's puzzles are brilliantly designed, if a little bit obtuse, however this was rarely a problem.

Overall the game is held down by it's combat and incredibly short length, and I was left wondering if maybe it wouldn't have been a better use of time creating a longer episode rather than releasing it in it's current length. However, it's puzzles, acting, design and incredible writing make this game a definite must play.
Great game. Definately one of the best kickstarted games that I have played

The Game is small but super clever. If you dont get another game this year get this one. I loved watching the walkthroughs just to see everyone was just as lost as i was playing it.

I feel a little sorry for The Fall,  or the developers behind it.  It's a good game in it's own right,  but it's inevitably going to be compared to other games, the most obvious of which is last year's indie darling The Swapper. I really liked The Swapper, but The Fall has far more in common with something like Flashback in terms of gameplay.


The Fall is a 2.5D adventure game. It's like a point & click with combat and platforming. You select an object to interact with by pointing at it, then choose how you're going to interact with it. You have an inventory, you'll be needing to combine these items with the objects in the gameworld to make progress. Unfortunately it being so like a point & click means The Fall also suffers from the same problems as your average point & click game does, but we'll come to that later.


What should mark The Fall out as interesting is its setting and tone, and that's where comparisons to The Swapper come in. You wake up on a desolate, dark space station, with gloom and foreboding swirling around you, and more than an inkling that you aren't getting the full story. You are actually the A.I. of a combat suit, your pilot is unresponsive so you must act to keep him safe, no matter what that requires. It's a great idea for a story and handles it well.


The Fall nails the look it's going for too, The Swapper's 'found object' art sometimes missed the mark, but The Fall looks and moves fantastic. It's a shame it doesn't do a bit more with its lighting, the sweeps of your torch against the backdrop look great, but it never really adds to the atmosphere other than looking good. Another aspect that is a nice touch and could have done with being expanded on is the OS. When Arid learns a new ability you have to go in to her OS to activate it, it kind of looks the part and it's a great idea, but it stops a little short of you feeling like it's more than a menu you don't really need.


There's also a surprising amount of personality and humour in the game considering you're dealing with A.I. the whole time, and that Arid (your character) is very much not programmed with a personality. Other characters are, but they still fit, the game is all about playing within the rules, and it itself manages this, adding colour without it feeling out of place.


I mentioned that The Fall's problems were those inherent within its genre and that's true. It's easy to miss things that can be interacted with or picked up. You use your torch to highlight things, but a quick sweep isn't always enough to mark something, so objects hidden high and low are easily missed. There were also a couple of occasions where 'solving' one part of a puzzle would drop new objects, but because of how dark the game is I couldn't see they'd been dropped. I know handholding in these kind of games can kill them, but there's times I wished interactable objects would sparkle a little.


The pace of the game is also a problem. When you reach a new area you'll find that you can't solve the first puzzle you come to, instead you'll have to go off and explore, with a later puzzle holding the key to solving the first puzzle. This is a problem for a couple of reasons, it's not signposted that you can't solve the early puzzle yet, so you'll struggle, wondering if it's your own stupidity that's halting progress, and probably more of an issue, it's a lot of downtime. Once you start solving puzzles though there's a real pace to them, you punch through them as you immediately recognise where this new item is going to be used.


Like Flashback there's also combat. It actually reminds me a little of the chunky gunplay of Shadow Complex. It's very modern but also feels simplified. You can take cover, even go invisible, but the key to success is timing. Enemies will present themselves for you to kill them, standing up and firing for 3 shots, then just waiting for you to take your turn before ducking behind cover again. That sounds like a damning sentence, but I doubt fluid combat is what you've come to The Fall for, and while it's not amazing, it's also not something I'd kick the game for.

The reason to play The Fall is probably the story. It's episode 1 of 3 apparently, but it ends in a way that I wouldn't mind if they didn't make another. Not that it's bad, more that it feels complete. You don't get all the answers, but you get enough. Hopefully though we do see an episode 2 and it builds on what's here, because The Fall, while not as good as some of the games it gets compared to, is still worth your time, and I'd venture is destined to be a Steam sale pick-up for a few, but it's worth getting on early.

Oh god yes. This is an amazing concept. If you like point and click adventure games, you're going to love this. Solutions might not be obvious time to time and might have to look up a walkthrough, but otherwise it's fine.

My only complaint is clunky controls. Aiming system is quite bad, when you unsheath your gun, you can't predict where it'll be facing. Could be better if the reticle was always on. Or there was a cursor on your screen.

Like I said, concept is good, execution, umm, meh. Regardless, 7/10

Bought it when it went on sale for 50% off based solely on the trailer. I hadn't heard of the game before and I probably should have researched before I bought, but as luck would have it the game proved to be a good purchase.

I ran through the whole thing in about 3 hours but I'll freely admit that I'm not very good at most game types this being no exception so someone quicker on the uptake could do it in less time. It runs like a point and click puzzle game but with a cover based shooting element which I felt livened the whole thing up quite a bit. But where the game can (at least arguably) truly shine is in the story. It centers on the interactions of a few different AI characters which while at times a bit tropey over all function to tell an engaging story. That of course is a matter of taste so make of that what you will.

Now the story does end in a cliff hanger but the team behind it promises another two games these will be sold separately (Based on the Kickstarter page) so be warned. Over all I would say that the game play offers a fun few hours and uses a number of cool mechanics making it at least worth a look and the story offers enough intrigue to warrant the purchase.

Fun and Engaging but Short and To be Continued

My hat goes off to Over the Moon Games, and cannot wait for the rest of the trilogy.

The fall combines exploration, problem solving and some light action to create a powerful mix. As you advance through the plot it becomes more interesting so it definitely leaves you wanting for more.

The atmosphere of the game is dark and you only have a flashlight with you, this makes it immersive, especially when you explore a zone for the first time. Some of the puzzles are a bit difficult, you will need to search for an item, and those can be hard to find. On more than one occasion the problem was that I didn't think of an alternative solution. But hey I prefer a challenge rather than a hint system telling me what to do all the time.

As I said before, the game has some brief action sections, in those you will aim your gun and try to take down your enemies. I played with a DualShock 3 and the aiming was not as precise as I would have liked, so a little bit of patience will be welcome.

But apart from those small problems, The Fall is a very interesting and entertaining game, it sets the mood perfectly and will surprise many. Give it a try!

The Fall has to have one of the most straight forward, yet engrossing and thought provacative, narratives I have seen in a game in some time. The game plays like a side scrolling mouse-shooter/ point and click adventure. It works rather well despite somewhat unusual (and innitialy cumbersome) control mapping, for both the combat and exploration. The pacing of the game's narrative is superb, and the puzzles are quite engaging, while staying logical, and organic to the environment, even if sometimes vague or easy to over think.  Its hard not to love this game, and the few blemishes it has do little to detract from the experience as a whole.

Wowzers, color me impressed! Another Kickstarter funded indie game has amazed me yet again. The atmosphere and story of this game is phenomenal. If you love science fiction stories and love adventure games The Fall is for you. The art style is very reminiscent of The Swapper and Limbo. The controls are tight and work great with a controller. The only negative thing that I can say about this game is that it’s the first part of a trilogy. So as soon as the game ends and you see To Be Continued..." on the screen

reviewText:
This game has one of the more interesting stories of the past years. While not entirely original it touches subjects that are rarely explored in video games. It has great atmosphere, likeable and relateable characters and a world that makes you want to know more about it. Beware: This is the first part of a series, the next title is currently in development.
The gameplay takes some getting used to but all in all it controls alright. The puzzles are interesting and just difficult enough to be engaging, yet not too frustrating.

All in all a great philosophical sci-fi adventure!

Play if you liked:
The Swapper. Gemini Rue. Primordia.

The Fall is a wonderful gem hidden about on steam. It's been years since I have gotten so intensely hooked on a story. Despite me being tired of platformers in general, I completely disregarded my disdain for 2D games just so I could take part of this highly engaging story. The gameplay is solid once you get it, and the art direction is coherent and moody, everything is in support of it's primary directive of great narrative. The game is not too difficult, though I found I got stuck a few times and had to look at a guide.\nSadly this is only part one, and I'm dying for the other part(s)? being released. If you like sci fi, morality, androids, AI, this game is worth a try.\nThe characters in this game are so well crafted, I can't think of any rivalling them at the top of my head.
Fascinating sci-fi story with a degree of subtelty that you don't often find in video games.  There are also masterful displays of dark humor.  Great voice acting, great visuals, great script.
Great game!! looking forward to the next episode!
Play this, it's awesome!

reviewText:
The dark atmosphere, and art direction make this a great game, along with some brilliant writing. Unfortunatley stopping this game from being truly great is the combat, which feels clunky and repetetive, however the game is saved by these sequences being relatively sparse.

It's puzzles are brilliantly designed, if a little bit obtuse, however this was rarely a problem.

Overall the game is held down by it's combat and incredibly short length, and I was left wondering if maybe it wouldn't have been a better use of time creating a longer episode rather than releasing it in it's current length. However, it's puzzles, acting, design and incredible writing make this game a definite must play.

I really enjoyed this game. It's kind of side-scroller, point and click adventure game with multiple puzzles and some combat scenes. It's very atmospheric and the sound is perfect. The story line is very compelling and has an ending that leaves you wanting to play the next episode. Voice acting was good, but I did experience a few glitches while playing. The puzzles were of decent difficulty, not too easy, but not too hard, as long as you keep trying. The combat parts, however, took a while to get down and could be irritating. The controls could be confusing also, and took a while to get used to. It's a pretty short game, since it only took me about 4 hours to complete, but it is part of a trilogy, so you can expect more soon. The main character is A.R.I.D., the AI of a combat suit, who takes over when her pilot lands in the depths of a mysterious facility. She needs find medical treatment for her unconscious pilot and must overcome environmental obstacles, as well as her own restrictive programming.

I would recommend this game, but with a lot of aprehension. The twists are kind of obvious, either because you're expecting them, or because you've read any science fiction novel which discusses AI in any capacity. Puzzles" can usually be solved by doing the standard adventure game
recommended: and then rub everything on everything
hoursPlayed:
but here it feels actually fairly relevant to the story. Repeated attempt at actions without necessarily understanding of why actually fits with the story, as you are essentially an aspect of a computer.

In fact, the reason I would recommend this game to begin with is that it very much gives me the experience of being an AI, at least in some regard. The somewhat awkward controls are obviously more atmospheric, and while the animation for jumping is a little less realistic, it lends itself to the more artificial nature of your entire being. The major complaint I have is partially that it starts in medias res, and oddly I think a lot of information that could be stated about this isn't given. For a game relying on the execution of the story, it does a good job at least in that regard, but it doesn't particularly scratch a deeper universe itch--at least in this stage.

Additionally, if you don't like To Be Continued"s

reviewText: I would recommend getting this game on sale. It's amazing and I loved everything about it. With only 3 hours of playtime 9.99 is steep. For 15 bucks I can get an entire month of being a space pirate or for 60 I can be an unstoppable force of destruction upon Mordor with well over 50 hours into that game.\n\n100% think everyone should play this and absolutely they should continue making them. But please please please find a way to put more content in.

The Fall has to have one of the most straight forward, yet engrossing and thought provacative, narratives I have seen in a game in some time. The game plays like a side scrolling mouse-shooter/ point and click adventure. It works rather well despite somewhat unusual (and innitialy cumbersome) control mapping, for both the combat and exploration. The pacing of the game's narrative is superb, and the puzzles are quite engaging, while staying logical, and organic to the environment, even if sometimes vague or easy to over think.  Its hard not to love this game, and the few blemishes it has do little to detract from the experience as a whole.

Portal + Deadspace = The Fall. Great atmosphere, dark humour, and (mostly) fun puzzles and combat.

Cons
-a few minor bugs (nothing major)
-the plot is a bit ho-hum and predictable (also ends on a bit of a cliffhanger)

Pros
-everything else

8/10; looking forward to the sequels

Hey, you! Yeah, you there! Want to hear about an absolutely fantastic game that you NEED to play? It’s this little indie gem called “The Fall,” devloped by the Kickstarter'd comanpy, Over the Moon Studios. Basically, it’s a short (4-6 hours) 2D sci-fi puzzle/shooter/existentialist crisis simualtor available for Mac, PC, Linux, and the Nintentdo Ambulance (WiiU! WiiU! WiiU!).

It's chock-full of gloriously Asimovian overtones, fantastic, frightening and chilling environments, fitting soundtrack, and, best of all, it leaves you with an indescribable emptiness after you finish the game.

You might be thinking, I'm not some Shakespearean teenager with daddy issues! I don't want to have to deal with such deep stuff

reviewText: Absolutely amazing. Game was definitely shorter than I would have liked, but the story was great. Can't wait for part 2

The Fall is an independent attempt to create a story-driven science fiction adventure game, and Over The Moon have efficiently delivered the atmosphere, the gameplay and the story.

There's really not much to talk about The Fall, however with the outstanding voiceacting and well-developed level design, it delivers what it promises - which is a story evolving around a suit called A.R.I.D. and it's urgency to get its pilot to a proper medical bay. While the game is relatively short, it's deliberate length actually adds to the atmosphere. And believe me, you'll find yourself wanting more at the very end.

Controls can be a bit of a problem time to time, exactly when you are to make a quick decision. This, actually, costed me a few achievements, unfortunately, but that is fine. I'm guessing The Fall is designed to be played with a controller, which I do not have since I pretty much would like to play anything with keyboard & mouse. - Anyway, there's nothing extra ordinary about the graphics. The dark atmosphere and the artstyle goes hand-in-hand and the overall graphics do add to the gameplay. Also, worth to note, I haven't had any performance related problems while playing The Fall on GNU/Linux. - which I am thankful for. It means a lot to see such titles on GNU/Linux and I apperciated every minute I've spent with The Fall on my Arch.

Voiceacting and Soundtrack are well done, there's nothing to add here. Sound Design is exactly how it should be and the Voiceactors gave their best for this title and they've succeed with an outstanding performance. - Very well done.

Does it worth its initial price? That might be debatable. But does it worth spending time with? Definitely. The Fall is one of those unique experiences for people who would like to explore different approaches to the genre. Again, it does what it promises and that's the exact reason why people who are interested in such games should give The Fall a try. - I promise, you won't regret it.

I'm looking forward for the new titles from Over The Moon, and of course the continuation of The Fall.

An excellent exploration and adventure game. It has a really great story if you like AI. The controls take some getting used to but are not obtuse. The game works hard to deliver a great atmosphere that compliments the story which is my favourite part of the game. ARID is well realised and a joy to watch as she combats the obsticles she faces and there are two other great characters you meet along the way.\nI can't wait for the next part to come out.

reviewText: Good but short if they give me the next episodes free i will be happy.\n

Interesting concept, play it with a controller, the game is surprisingly short, not worth 10 bucks but still pretty good, just be aware, the game gives you a massive sequel hook, and that's kind of not cool if you ask me.

Just finished this today.

The easiest way to sum The Fall up would be to say it's a story-driven atmospheric point-and-click adventure that draws inspiration from Limbo and sometimes feels like Dead Space.

It's a rather short game (beat it in ~4 hours), but includes an interesting narrative and story. (Make sure you're paying attention to details and it gets really good) Fantastic use of characters and setting. It was genuinely creepy even when nothing was happening. The controls are less than perfect and there are some bugs, but they didn't get in the way too much. It felt a bit lacking at first, and I have to say the combat is by far the worst part, but what's there is fun and creative. The final boss is seriously lacking though.

Play this one all the way through if you pick it up; the ending sequence is one of the better I've seen from indie stories.

A great mix between Point-and-Click adventure with light side-scroller shooting elements. But that isn't what shine's in this title, the story is the centerstage and it is engrossing and compelling.\n\nA deffinite recommendation for anyone who is a fan of science-fiction and philosophy.
The ending made me feel empty inside. 11/10
10/10 adventure, who would have thought?\nOnly one con: it's in three parts and part 2 is only in development.

After that you're on your own to figure out what to do and where to go.\n\nI did not run into any "game breaking bugs" or glitches that I can recall. I did have an issue with not being able to fire while using an xbox 360 controller. I fixed it by turning off my wireless mouse. Not sure if they have found a fix
recommended: but they are aware of it.\n\nThe games sound and visuals add nicely to the atmosphere. The voice acting
hoursPlayed: sound effects and music really speak for themselves. Graphics are not mind blowing but still satisfying.\n\nOverall I really liked the game. I do plan on playing through again. If you call yourself a gamer then you really should play The Fall. It's quite the gem. :)"

reviewText: It was very short, but the art style in the game appeals to me. Ending was a bit depressing.

It's an adventure game with a fair bit of snooping through tunnels and maintenence shafts and interesting puzzles that actually connect to the story, rather than serving as obstacles to the rest of the plot. Every puzzle solution teaches us something about our protagonist and her situation.

Excellent writing, superb characters, even better dialogue.

It's 3-4 hours long, and ends on a cliffhanger, but it's the first in a series, so the only flaw I can imagine is impatience on the part of the player. And frankly that's your problem, not the devs'.

This game had me a bit torn.

The Fall is a point-and-click style adventure game with occasional combat sequences and follows the story of the AI A.R.I.D. The game is really short and is only prolonged by the time it takes you to figure out the puzzles. That's not to say it's bad, though. I quite like the narrative themes and the artstyle. It really reminds me a lot of The Swapper, another puzzle game which also used a really gloomy atmosphere and had a similarly introspective story, which I also enjoyed.

The game does however suffer from the same things that just about any point-and-click does. The formula of Use X on Y to trigger Z" can be really obtuse and hard to figure out at times
date: especially if you also happen to miss a notification or item because you didn't use your flashlight in a certain spot. On the flip side of the coin however
recommended: it feels really satisfying when you actually manage to figure them out.\n\nReally the game feels like a glorified demo or a proof of concept
hoursPlayed: and I would really like to see it expanded and improved upon. If you can get it at a discount
voteText: I would definitely recommend you give it a try."

reviewText:
The fall is a 2D side scrolling game with a game play focus on solving puzzles, a disturbing setting and questions about AI, robots and their behavior.

The puzzles are not hard, but the mechanic of the flashlight makes interacting with objects clunky almost as much as the combat.

But this game's focus is clearly not the action, but the ideas it throws around.

Are robots alive? How should they be treated? What happens when robots have no use for humans, no one to serve.

These are executed in a very simple but satisfying way in this game. Its great for a short and interesting play, but it has no replay value.

An highly atmospheric mystery.

Just from the walk and movement of the suit you are immediately feeling like an AI controlling the game.
Voice acting is top notch, and goes perfectly with the well written story. Audio and visuals can't get anything but top marks.

A must buy for any fan of either scifi, mystery, or adventure games. Don't go in expecting focus on shooting mechanics. It's there, and competently implemented, but firefights total to maybe 10 minutes of gameplay throughout the game, and you will likely only mess up once of twice.

It's not very long game, but neither does it waste your time. No mechanic is needlessly repeated for padding, which I personally appreciate.

At it's core, the Fall is a short - hopefully episodical - Point&Click platformer, having you play an Artificial Intelligence Suit trying to rescue it's unconcious pilot. Playing as the AI puts a new spin on the old subject of Robo-ethics. It's also surpsiningly polished, creating a small yet immersive environment and the voice-acting puts bigger games to shame.\n\n2 thumbs up!
Great game. A little bit short, but great. Puzzles are logical and not dumbed down, so expect a fair challenge ;)
