reviewText:
Very atmospheric game with pretty cool visuals.  I like the puzzle/action hybrid, and the limitations on the controls (namely, you can't use the flashlight if you are shooting) makes the simple interface challenging.  Some of the puzzles seemed to be a little obtuse, and I'll admit I cheated with a guide when I got stuck, but most of the other puzzles were very rewarding (the baby gave me no end of chuckles, you'll know what I mean when you get there).

My only negative (other than the difficult puzzles, but that's more my shortcomings ;)  ) is that sometimes you have to interact with items that do not have the highlighted inspection box, which made things a little awkward because the vast majority of itmes on screen you cannot interact with.

All in all, a really fun game, especially since I picked it up on one of the sales on steam, so it was definitely a pleasant surprise.  Here's to hoping that the developers can put together the remainder of the trilogy.  Looking forward to more stories for A.R.I.D.
I liked the atmosphere and the game mechanics. A good game, with a great story. Totally recommend it!

I won't go into too much detail about The Fall's storyline, as you can check the store page for that if you haven't already.  Instead, I'll talk about the rest of it so far as January 2015.

This game is thankfully uncomplicated in its control scheme and gameplay mechanics, and the atmosphere of it is seriously tense and dramatic - perfect for dystopia effectionadoes.  The game is quite reliant on problem solving, and many of the methods for dealing with situations have results that seem a little unorthodox - which, while fitting the theme and story very well, can leave one rather frustrated.

However, for those of us who don't want to miss out on the rest of the story because of one little puzzle, there's thankfully a number of walkthroughs out there that can help you.  Alternatively, since there isn't much that directly hinges on doing things in a set order (that I know of anyway), the tactic of brute-force use-everything-with-everything and do-everything-again-just-to-see-what-happens thing can work.

The combat system is fairly decent too, and while currently lacking in variety, due to the relatively low health and shields of your character it can be rather intense.  Also, quite fortunately, there are frequent saving points before combat situations so that if you die, you won't be too far behind.

All in all, I like this game and I recommend it to anybody who's got a bit of time up their sleeves and an itching for a gritty and dark puzzle game.
It is an adventure game with janky controls and puzzles wrapped around a great story with good voice acting.

I bought this game after listening to Giant Bomb's Game of the Year podcasts, where they named it Best Story and soundly spoiled a twist or two, so I went in with expectations. And, to be honest, neither the storytelling nor the story lived up to their high praise.

It starts off really, really good. The first 30 minutes *is* outstanding: mysterious, menacing, brilliantly told and stunningly visualized. If there's one thing this game nails it's robots talking to other robots, and it offers perhaps the best representation of robot 'culture' (if there is such a thing) in sci-fi that I've seen. The world is weird, the characters are weirder, and the atmosphere is thick throughout.

But then you run into the puzzles. I'm not an adventure gaming veteran or anything like that - I've played a few in my time - but the puzzles in The Fall are *so* obscure, *so* out-of-left-field and backtrack-y that it immediatly halts any momentum or goodwill the game conjures up in the first 30 minutes, deciding instead to take a hour long detour into pure puzzle-solving that feels like fluff to a game that's already achingly short (my steam time is 2 hours). Here, the story not so much evolves as mutates, getting sidetracked from the initial danger and wonder of that first half-hour. It continues to explore some interesting philosophical approaches to robots (though not particularly unheard of ones), but starts loosing its footing quickly.

The ending is a little stronger, buoyed by more directive and a brutal ending, but too many of the motivations behind characters are left unclear and combat - while unobtrusive but never exceptional in the earlier parts of the game - starts to become an annoying crutch. Since you are so fragile and your combat options are so limited, throwing more enemies than you can handle coupled with bad controls was incredibly frustrating in the final 20-stretch. By the time the game reached its climactic confrontation, I just wanted it to be done.

Luckily, about five minutes later it was. Both a blessing and a curse, The Fall's 2 hour run-time gives it a pleasant short-stort feel while still leaving questions open for the next two chapters. However, it's too short to give one character in particular much interesting motivation, which isn't great because there are only three in the entire game. The story itself is...unexceptional, though, for the most part, well told. The main character, A.R.I.D., and a friendly (or is it?) computer AI she meets along the way are both well voiced and written, and the world they inhabit is always fun to explore, if not being the most fleshed-out. Some character beats, however, fall totally flat - mainly one weird 'morality' choice near the end comes out of nowhere and means next-to-nothing.

Did listening to the Game of the Year stuff bias me against this game? Maybe. Probably. But in a year where we had good, emotional storytelling it The Wolf Among Us and This War of Mine, The Fall barely holds a candle to the rest. It didn't hit me as particularly better than other indie-sci-fi games (if you want a great one, go buy The Swapper). Overall, it just didn't feel that special. It never could live up to those first 30 minutes.

This is unfortunately a game with lots of wasted potential. The biggest reason for this is the controls, it simply doesn't work and makes you frustrated throughout the entire game (this applies to both keyboard/mouse and controller). Another reason is that the puzzles are being more or less spelled out to you whenever you find clues.

Will I play the second game in the triology when it releases? Most likely not. Should reviews point out significant changes to the above, then maybe, just maybe.

I really wish I could recommend this game, but I can't.

reviewText:
This 2d side scroller is essentially a point and click adventure game with some shooting elements that break it up a bit that sometimes feel slightly too hard. Yet the checkpoints are ususally fair enough that it is not much of a problem.

As an adventure/puzzle game, its puzzles range the gambit of plot advancing clever to requiring me to pull out the gamefaqs. None the less, this game is an enjoyable short experience and one that I would recommend.

The story, dialog, and the bleak world ARID finds herself (itself?) in are the real draws here. A notable plot/game mechanic is that many of ARID's abilities are locked behind logic gates that require you to subvert her own directives in order to fulfill her ultimate goal (Prime Directive) of saving her unconscious and in critical condition's pilot life. This leads to a rather ominous progression that was enjoyable to watch as she moves about a bleak and ruined world that I want to learn more about.

This is a short game, only about 3 hours long as its only the first episode, however I very much look forward to seeing how this story will end.

10/10 will play again.

The Fall as everyone else has said by now is one of the best experiences (at least in my opinion) to come out of a video game in awhile. ONE OF. It's not the top one but is probably top ten IF not top 5. Anyway

The game isn't atrociously impossible yet still challenging at least where the puzzles are concerned. The combat isn't all that difficult, take cover, shoot, stealth destroy droids and take their energy for yourself, camo when necessary, etc etc. The puzzles are creative. (Especially the baby one) And the game is about 3 hours long depending on how quickly you complete puzzles. The dark story coupled with the foreboding atmosphere are the best qualities of the game and really sell the game. Oh did I mention that A.I are awesome and scary at the same time.

Not much else I can say about the game without getting into spoilers so go try it out its fun, requires you to think and starts out poking you like a younger sibling trying to get arise out of you to full on curb stomping you by the end.

Enjoy

This game is a great way to experience Asimov's 3 laws of robotics with you playing as the robot. The game doesn't explicitly cite Asimov, but the Laws are clearly the source of your operating parameters and constraints. They serve as stand-ins for ethics, morality, and what drives us all.

Bottom Line: Play this game if you have $5 and 5 hours. At that price point and time commitment, you'll get great value.

Hint: The controls are a little wonkey. If you have a game pad, the controls make more sense than a keyboard.

The fall takes the great question of how far may robotics push their directives and puts it right back on the table. With very stout story telling, the point and click style allows you to set the pace that you want to. The ambient sounds and drawn up world was well put together and the dark setting will have you pondering what happened throughout the entire game. The clunky combat system is not the forte of this title, but gives just enough threat of violence that youd just rather avoid it. The protagonist is one to grab hold of and understand more clearly giving an even bigger appreication for every choice you make. Ultimately, the story throws you for a loop and in the end your purpose is completely new

Honestly, I was pretty surprised with how much I enjoyed this game. The word combat usually is a big turn off for me (usually because I have the reflex of a sloth), but I was very pleased to find that the fighting system was not the main focus and was relatively easy to work with.
In total, the puzzles were challenging, but not too impossibly difficult to figure out. I only ended up getting stuck about 3  times and that was because I failed to closely examine the ceiling or the floor. (I'm looking at you glass jar =3= )
My only complaint would be that the aiming/targeting system could be a biiiiiiit iffy at times. Was a bit annoying I'd find myself facing the wrong direction while trying to fight for my life.
All in all though, this was a fantastic game. The story was incredibly absorbing and the voice acting was a pleasure to listen to. Not to mention the art style was absolutely beautiful
Can't wait until the next game. Will definitely be buying

Toward the beginning of January I was listening to the Giant Bomb year-end awards podcasts, and they mentioned some stuff about The Fall that made it sound appealing. Also, it was on the Steam sale for some absurdly cheap amount. So I bought it, and then actually played it. Gasp. Here are some thoughts.

The story pretty much immediately had me sold, because I love sci-fi and I love sci-fi about artificial intelligences even more. Excession is my favorite Culture book. Ship Minds are the best and I love Gray Matter forever. The Fall puts you in charge of a suit whose AI is given the task of finding medical assistance for the nonresponsive human inside the suit. The game combines elements of a point-and-click adventure game with sidescrolling movement and combat schemes. I was skeptical about this, but they mesh together fairly smoothly.

As ARID, the AI in the suit, you must follow your operating parameters while you look for help for your human. However, circumstances occasionally dictate their circumvention for optimal performance. The Fall is the story of how an artificial intelligence rationalizes its actions. With no human to turn to for guidance, ARID must make frequent value judgments and do things that perhaps no AI should - but as long as it’s to save the pilot of the suit, the ends justify the means.

The psychology of The Fall isn’t advanced by any means - it’s very Psych 101. But it’s fun to see it applied to artificial intelligences, and the concepts mesh with the story and gameplay seamlessly. My first play-through felt pretty mind-blowing, but going back through the game a second time it was easier to suss out the basic concepts and allegory underlying the game’s framework. Still, the first play-through is what counts.

Some lists (people love lists, I hear):

Pros:

Story/gameplay interaction - certain story elements actually inform the gameplay (or is it the other way around?). Always fun to feel like the story and gameplay are working in harness rather than tripping each other up.
Story conceits are integrated naturally - the dialogue has a lot to do with this, I think. The concepts that come up feel like they are occurring as a natural result of the things that are happening in the story and not because someone wanted to shoehorn some “deep” stuff into the game.
Voice acting - I am not a huge fan of VA in general, but the artists in this game do a FANTASTIC job. In particular I want to single out ARID’s voice, which starts very robotically and gradually reflects more and more looseness as the subversion of its protocols continues throughout the game. But really, all the voices are great. Num num num.
MY IMMERSION - I played with headphones on which helped, but the visuals and sound are very atmospheric and engaging. It’s definitely a game that sucks you in.

Cons:

Typical adventure game frustrations - everyone has these, right? Once you solve the puzzle you look back at it and think, how did I ever miss that? but while you’re unable to figure it out, you feel like you’re bashing your head into a rock. The Fall has blessedly few of these moments, but they’re still there.
Back-tracking - at a certain point in the story the game world opens up quite a bit, and it can be frustrating to try to figure out where you’re supposed to go next, which can result in a lot of running back to an area to see if there’s something you missed, or if something changed. It’s a common thing in adventure games especially, but my roommate in particular had a big problem with it.
Combat issues - surprisingly few of these as well, but there are a few hiccups: between myself and my roommate we found a few places where you could get stuck on the environment in odd ways (while taking cover), and sometimes the enemies respawn in a frustrating fashion if you move away from their areas and back into them again. Fortunately there aren’t many combat situations in the game, so these gripes are pretty minor.

The Fall isn’t a game you can sink dozens of hours in. My first play-through took about three hours and a subsequent second run-through took one hour. The length is nice, though, because the game is so immersive that it’s really best if you finish it in one sitting. Currently it’s on Steam for ten bucks, which isn’t bad for three hours of amusement. When you finish, you can make your friends play it! Snicker under your breath as they get stuck on puzzles you solved effortlessly! Curse their names as they solve all the puzzles that frustrated you! It’s fun for the whole family!

For real, though, if you like adventure games, or sci-fi games, or games about artificial intelligences and psychology, you should pick this up. And if it’s on sale pick it up anyway and give it a shot.

reviewText: A very captivating and mysterious game. You play as an AI suit, your goal is to protect the unconscious pilot inside the suit. A beautiful sci-fi indie game that oozes atmosphere.  Some of the puzzles I found were quite obscure, but not too difficult.  The combat system is slightly off I found, but that was never the purpose of the game particularly so doesn't matter too much.  The main achievement and the thing that sticks in my mind is the suit's operating system and how the AI reacts...  The dialogue is well written and acted, it works perfectly all together to make an interesting platform puzzle sci-fi (almost horror) game.  Superb, highly recommended.

I would desribe this game as an excellent and tightly designed interactive short story. It provides an excellent and interesting look at the familiar science fiction questions. Such as What does it mean to be self-aware?"  and "What is the difference between and A.I and a human?". The gameplay although is simple and consists of puzzles and gunfights. The puzzles involves finding items and correctily determining when and how to use them with little hints and advice beyond the logic of the situation. The gunfights involves simple duck and pop out to shoot mechanics. The story however is the heart of this game. Throughout it the characters and the well voiced dialogue pulls you along and never lets up. You hear and feel the growing personal awarness of the main character (an AI). I finished the game in one sit down but it was a memorable 3 hours. When i finished i leaned back on my chair and thought more about themes and ideas presented in this wonderful story.\n\nI recommend the game if you want an interactive and decent science fiction story that plays with familiar tropes and the themes."
The game was pretty awesome but way too short for its price... You can finish it in about 1 hour or 2...

The general conceit is that the player takes the role of an Artificial Intelligence. As such
date: your actions are constrained to your directives. For instance
recommended: the player is not allowed to lie in order to solve what should be a trivial puzzle. This does mean that the moments of "railroading" in the story tend to make sense: they are the only action that the player can take given the directives they have.\n\nAbout the only thing that I seriously disliked was the combat. The control scheme is NOT conducive to side-scrolling mouse-and-keyboard gunplay. Given that an early upgrade allows for the player to evade gunfire simply by tapping a button

Brilliant writing, voice acting, and sound design, but somewhat hindered by clunky environmental interaction and combat. If you value a good story and an interesting setting, you'll find that this game's strengths easily outpace its weaknesses.

I do generally find games that explore the nature of self-awareness in A.I to be interesting and this game does well in exploring it.

Less astute individuals such as myself may have trouble with a number of the puzzles, a few of which were solved by basically using every item on every thing out of frustration. (plus a couple I just couldn't figure out on my own)

However, it IS a good game, with a quietly unsettling and isolated atmosphere and a solid story that has plenty to work with in the aftermath. It has a sense of questioning at several points that personally left me wondering about the actions I was taking and I ultimately walked away with chills down my spine once things were made clear.

A fun and thoughtful little game, with excellent voice-work and a good, well-presented narrative.

However, it must be said that THE FALL’s strong points are mainly visual or relating to the atmosphere of the game .The overall experience is hampered by an underlying mystery that is frankly quite obvious from the start, while other questions remain unanswered even at the end of the game (two additional episodes might be released in the future). The game’s puzzles are usually solvable without Walkthrough assistance, but it is not always clear ”why” something worked. Especially around the mid-part, there are some typical examples of Moon Logic with solutions that defy common sense or seem needlessly complicated. The game is short – possible to complete under three hours – for which reason I cannot recommend a purchase for the full price of 10 €. Wait for a steam sale.

Still, I really liked THE FALL so I’m going to recommend it. It has a great feel to it and it generates some interesting food for thought. At its core, THE FALL seems to be a story about an AI (ARID) interacting with other AIs, struggling – however superficially – with questions of raison d’être, behavioural limitations and the relationship between objectives and the means to realise them. These essentially human questions find an intriguing context when presented to beings which are not human, but are forced to behave as such when finding themselves in a dark unforgiving place, cut off from their makers.

Is it perfect? No. Is it worth your time? Yes.

Aesthetically well designed, with beautiful use of lighting and very good voice acting.  Slightly unintuitive controls, but not to a degree that notably impedes enjoyment.  A very engaging story-telling experience.\n\nOverall, very enjoyable.  Highly reccomended.

reviewText: Wow - I just finished The Fall a few minutes ago, having started it this morning, and wow, what a game!\n\nThe biggest reason to get this game is definitely the story. A.R.I.D, the AI controlling the suit, and her driving motivation to save the man inside, provides an extremely interesting main character that is surprisingly human for being such a convincing artificial intelligence. One of the most interesting aspects of the story is how far an AI should be willing to go to perform its primary function, an example being A.R.I.D breaking several of her protocols in order to indirectly further her cause of protecting the suit's occupant, and her interaction with other AI not so willing to do the same. Overall, the story is very intriguing, with a small but extremely likeable (or, in some cases, frightening) cast
date:
with some great voice acting and a tremendous cliffhanger.

The gameplay is also extremely well-done. Light plays a relatively important role, and the flashlight on your gun must be used to reveal clues or enable actions in order to continue. Doing this is the majority of the game, but doesn't feel repetetive, given that the main purpose is exploring, and this is how you explore. The puzzles are very cleverly done, but sometimes /too/ clever, and can take a long time to solve. Also, given that every clue can be interacted with generally and individually with every item in your inventory and you have no idea which one, if any, is the correct solution, after being stuck for a while, I started trying everything with anything that was remotely promising. Obviously this is not intended to be done, so I would recommend trying to avoid it and to think the puzzles through as much as possible, but sometimes the solution can be really obscure. Combat can be intense and difficult, and has been done pretty well. I preferred the smaller fights with a gun that needed a second or two to charge before firing early in the game more than the more frantic fights later on, but it was all good, and the final boss fight was epic!

The graphics and sound effects are amazing! Graphics are really well done, especially the lighting effects, and the animation is strong as well. It's not perfect, and there are times when one animation visibly skips to another, or you can see outside the map, but these issues are minor and won't hurt the immersion unless you let it. The sound effects and music are well done and spooky, and, especially when using earbuds/earphones, really capture the mood.

Basically, this game is amazing! Short, yes, but there's more to come to finish the fantastic story, which I can't wait for! If you like immersive games, difficult puzzles, an amazing story, and especially AI, you will absolutely love this game. Ten dollars may end up being a bit much if another ten has to be payed for the next two parts as well, but I'm not sure that it will, and even then it's probably worth it. If it's on sale, though, seven dollars or under, don't hesitate to buy it!

TL;DR - Buy it on sale to be joyful.

Decent if clunky mechanics, a compelling story, and some fun puzzles make The Fall a pretty worthwhile experience, especially since I got it on sale.  Unfortunately, I had no idea it was only the first part of a larger game until I hit the ending, which was a huge cliffhanger, and it only took me 3 hours to reach that.  Thankfully, the devs have already confirmed that its other parts are being made and will be released.\n\nSo, based on the quality of what is here, I would recommend The Fall, but only with the caveat that you should probably wait until the whole package is released; otherwise you'll find yourself with an extremely short and unsatisfying experience that only hints at something interesting.

While there are just a couple minor complaints (some puzzles solutions may seem a little too obscure; controls felt a little strange initially), they can easily be overlooked for a fantastic story woven in with entertaining gameplay.\nI was pleasantly surprised by the humor (sometimes dark, sometimes slapstick) that kept cropping up, bringing a little levity to a story that could have easily been made too heavy.  Well done and well worth your time.

In a brilliant cliffhanger, you'll find yourself wanting more, as this is the first chapter of a 3 part saga. AMAZING

So and for all still reading:
The Fall is the first of three games of a series(parts 2 and 3 are in development). It is quite short, but it offers an evening of great entertainment. It's a lovel atmospheric puzzler with decent combat mechanics thrown in too

The story in this game is simply incredible. It feels like it takes inspiration from Asimov for its Artificial Intelligence based story, and it is certainly written just as well. And the voice acting, simply stunning. I would argue that ARID's performance is at least on par with that of GlaDOS. ARID's development over time made this so compelling.

It's hard not to spoil this game. But I should also say that it's relatively short, and the gameplay is composed of a modest point and click adventure with clunky combat inbetween. It's appropriate for the atmosphere, but the puzzles ranged from incredibly easy to completely unintuitive with little in between. Nevertheless, I expect the sequel (which is in development, I hear) to improve these elements.

I regret missing the kickstarter, I hope I can contribute in the future, though.

Contrary to what the trailers (and, at first, the interface) suggested to me, The Fall plays like a point-and-click adventure game. Maybe you're better at watching trailers than I am and interpreted it better, but I was really expecting much more of a Metroidvania than I got. I'm not about to complain, though. The game that The Fall turned out to be was, I think, a much better game than what I was expecting when I bought it. However, I do have to agree with other reviewers on one point: It's pretty short. I beat it in about three and a half hours and I wasn't even particularly bright about it.

You are A.R.I.D., the artificial intelligence aboard a mark-7 combat suit, activated in order to ensure the survival of your comatose pilot. You run swiftly up against the limits of your own programming, and as many of the game's puzzles involve circumventing internal obstacles as external ones. It sets up an exceptionally well-written narrative as A.R.I.D. interacts with the bizarre underground facility it finds itself in, and the people that live there. Do note on that point that The Fall is the first game of a planned trilogy; the story ends on a maddening cliffhanger with fewer questions answered than not, and I can scarcely contain my anticipation for the second installment.

Gameplay sits comfortably between the likes of a point-and-click adventure game and a cerebral, puzzle-heavy platformer; kind of a LucasArts adventure game[en.wikipedia.org] meets Blackthrone. Combat, I'm sorry to say, is nowhere near as interesting as the trailer seems to promise. You're given a handgun with a flashlight which allows you to examine your surroundings, and soon the option to switch to lasersight mode to shoot, though you'll spend a good 80% of the game in flashlight mode. With the exception of one sequence near the end, the shooting parts can typically be solved by strolling forward and aiming loosely for heads; though the cover tutorial section promises otherwise, your foes are largely too few, too far between, and far too inept to be terribly threatening. This is to The Fall's credit, I think. Despite being a combat AI loaded onto a suit of power armour, fighting isn't really what you're doing here.

Special mention needs to be given to the dialogue. The writing is outstanding, and the voice acting is some of the best I've heard anywhere, indie game or otherwise. A.R.I.D.'s voice actress is particularly superb, which you might not expect from the flat monotone of the trailers. I can't expound particularly on that point without risk of spoilers, so you'll just have to take my word for it on that one.

TL;DR: If you're into thinky adventure games and don't mind waiting for the other two games, this is well worth picking up now. If you're not patient enough to wait on the plot to resolve itself, wait on it a bit, but absolutely get it later when the other two come out. And if you don't care for story or puzzles, give it a pass. In the interests of disclosure, I picked it up in a Humble Bundle; I didn't want to pay full price for it at the time, but after having played it I'm convinced it would've been worth it.
Atmospheric, tough puzzles, and an interesting plot makes this game very enjoyable.

Highly recommended. I didn't back this game on Kickstarter, but after playing it I would back a sequel.

That being said, the game wasn't what I expected it to be. When I first saw it on Steam it was compared it to Dead Space and something else that I can't remember. It resembles Dead Space a little in atmosphere, but not in gameplay. There are some action shooting elements, but there are even more adventure game elements (ie. picking up an item and using it somewhere else). I normally don't have the patience for adventure games at all (I don't think I've ever finished one), but The Fall wasn't obtuse enough to frustrate me. You never have very many items in your inventory, and you never really have to combine them so if all else fails you can complete most puzzles using trial and error.

One more note: I wasn't rushing, and I managed to beat the game in under 4 hours. Some might consider that a negative, but with my huge backlog I thought it was a plus.

Great game for anyone looking for something new to fill an afternoon.

Well, it's short. I got stumped a few times and still finished the game in just under four hours. It's heavily story-based so the re-play value is probably a bit low -- but that is a problem with the genre, not the game itself.

But was it worth the 10 bucks? Definitely. The art is pretty (if a bit hard to see at times), the sound and voice acting is great and the gameplay is pretty solid. But most importantly: despite the difficulty of some of the puzzles, I enjoyed the game through and through.

Some players were annoyed that the ending is a bit of a cliff-hanger -- but I'd argue that it reveals just enough to allow the game to stand on its own. There are tons of open questions left and it's not guaranteed that they will be answered in any of the future chapters. It's not a game for those who obsess over getting 100%" of a game
date: but that is intentional. Good storytelling is based on telling you just enough to keep you interested
recommended: not boring you with exhaustive details.\n\nA++ would buy again."

This game, while very short (it only took me about 3-4 hours to beat), manages to thrust me head first into it's dark and mysterious world and left me wanting more. Just as the title describes, the game starts with a combat suit falling to an unknown place from an unknown source. You play as the onboard A.I. trying to save her pilot and struggling with the fact that she might be malfunctioning.
Throughout the game you will encounter many challenges and puzzles that are common of a point and click game but it is mixed with a solid cover-focused combat system. Overall I never found this system tiring growing stale as the difficulty ramps up throughout as well as you obtain several upgrades that help in combat.
To conclude, I say play this game. If you don't want to pay the asking price of $10 at least buy it when it's on sale. The cliffhanger ending left me wanting more but according to the game there will be a second part; I patiently await the second installment fervently.

tl;dr: Get this game if you like dark sci-fi action and/or point and click games.

reviewText: Fantastic Game, brilliant gameplay and a fantastic concept, I look forward to further installments to continue the progress of ARID.
Adventure with a very Banksian feel. It's very short.

I've found this game to be an invigorating experience. It's engaging, to say the least. The story will draw you in, the puzzles can make you scratch your head and slap yourself for derping about, and the combat is... well, it's not difficult, but it too is entertaining. All in all, I had a blast, and frankly, I would suggest this game to anyone who enjoys a good adventure.

Great Story
Appropriately Gloomy Art Design
Amazing Voice Acting
And Puzzles That Require Outside The Box" Thinking To Solve

An Overall Fantastic Way To Spend An Afternoon."

The Fall seems to be the first episode of ARID, an AI in a military suit programed to protect their pilot who has become unconcsious from the sudden fall from space. The rest of your journey follows ARID as she embarks on a journey to get medical attention for pilot Joseph. Along the way she meets help from the mainframe, and an opposing force in the Caretaker. It is a harrowing adventure posed with danger and many hard decisions, but ARID is willing to go through everything to save Joseph.

The game is pretty short, but the ending is quite satisfying in leaving a want for sequel. Gameply wise it isn't anything too difficult, but one can argue that the puzzle solving isn't too straightforward and may turn into a guess and check. The shooting is straightforward as well, but I do recommend that you only go for headshots because the enemies can be quite difficult. Overall it is just a side scroller puzzle adventure game with some shooting elements.

The story is definitely  the strongest point in the game, and charater growth is something that becomes so powerfully moving. When you see the mainframe in danger you do feel angry at the Caretaker and it drives you to hunt him down. As you see what lengths ARID is willing to go, you can't help but sympathize with her strength to make tough decisions.  And as the mainframe tries to help ARID you feel this strong camaraderie from him. The ending as I said before gives the short story and nice bow to wrap everything up. Would definitely play a sequel if it comes out.

The Fall is a great story based game that for some will demand a sequel, but some may not be influenced enough to look past the simple game mechanics which would also be fair. The Fall looks great and will in fact create the mood of exploration and impending doom. It is a little bit guess and check with the puzzles, but that can quickly be overlooked with the setting as stated before. The shooting parts are actually a fun reprieve from the little exploring and puzzle solving you must do. A fun little game that should be on your list of purchases, sale price or otherwise.

Storytelling and atmosphere are exceptionally good.  The Fall is trippy, though-provoking and immersive, with an original and interesting premise.

The only downsides for me were:
- Controls felt clumsy (keyboard and mouse).  Maybe this is better with a gamepad.
- It's fairly short.

With those two caveats, I think this game was definitely well worth the asking price, and I heartily recommend it.

I'm not good at puzzles, okay?). It's a bit short, but apparently it's episode 1 out of 3, and I'm really looking forward to the next episode. It was $9 well spent. Try out The Fall for yourself.

The Fall is an interesting game. The voice acting, sounds, and atmosphere are engaging.  However, I don't feel that the game was quite what it should have been.  (*Mild Spoilers Ahead*)  In the beginning of the game, you crash land on an uncharted planet, and have no idea where you are or how you got there.  Your primary objective is to find medical treatment for your human pilot. This is where I feel that the devs missed a huge opportunity.  Since this is the primary objective, there is (as far as I can tell) no real emphasis on the planet you're on.  No information other than that you're near the very edge of the galaxy.  There's no story as to how the facility you explore came to be as it is.

There was huge potential for a creepier, more thrilling story that was (again, as far as I can tell) simply thrown away. (*Spoilers End*)

The gameplay itself is simple but interesting (especially combat). The puzzles are difficult but not necessarily intuitive; you have to really pay attention to the events going on around you to find a way forward, and you must look for anything you can pick up and use.

Overall, the game is worth a buy - if it is on sale.  I don't really feel that the money I spent was wasted, but I also don't feel that it was well spent.  Buy this if you have some extra cash that you feel like rolling on something.  Otherwise, wait for it to go on sale.

reviewText: Oh my... Words cannot describe how spectacular I feel this game is though I will do my best. This game is a point-and-click adventure game with segments of side-scrolling shooting mixed in. You play as an AI of a damaged combat suit following its directives: Do not lie, obey orders from its human pilot, and ensure the safety of said pilot. Throughout the game you discover many other AIs/Andriods/Combat suits who will be both a help and a hinderance in your goal: Assessing the vital signs of your human pilot, which are unknown as your scanner was damaged after a crash landing. This game brings to life many of the questions many of scientists are faced with today in developing AIs, from the singularity, self-awareness, and disobedience of protocols. Well, it's short. I got stumped a few times and still finished the game in just under four hours. It's heavily story-based so the re-play value is probably a bit low -- but that is a problem with the genre, not the game itself.

But was it worth the 10 bucks? Definitely. The art is pretty (if a bit hard to see at times), the sound and voice acting is great and the gameplay is pretty solid. But most importantly: despite the difficulty of some of the puzzles, I enjoyed the game through and through.

Some players were annoyed that the ending is a bit of a cliff-hanger -- but I'd argue that it reveals just enough to allow the game to stand on its own. There are tons of open questions left and it's not guaranteed that they will be answered in any of the future chapters. It's not a game for those who obsess over getting 100%" of a game
date: but that is intentional. Good storytelling is based on telling you just enough to keep you interested
recommended: not boring you with exhaustive details.\n\nA++ would buy again."

The Fall is a 2-d point-and-click adventure game with some action/platform elements. The ambiance and story were very inventive, and the voice acting in general was surprisingly good. It works better as a story than as a game. The game is a little bit buggy for me, sometimes my guy would get stuck and I had to restart the game. Since this is an indy game this is not a huge surprise. The story is a very dark sci-fi tale in a kind of post-apocalyptic setting. The action and platforming elements were not great, the controls were just not tight enough for a good action game experience. For sci-fi adventure game fans, this game is worth a look. If you are expecting a good 2-d action game, best to move on to The Swapper, or Braid, or Fly'n, or Trine, or even Bastion.

The Fall....... a game i purchased on a impulse buy and in the hopes that it would be in the same league as Limbo, after beating it i regret nothing and the fall definitely surpassed expectations . One of the few games that the story has gripped me within a few minutes of playing and even after finishing it has left me sinking in the subplots that are hinted throughout the whole game making the end open to interpretation until the future episodes are released. Sadly the Game is short and is currently in an episodic format with no release date for next episodes. The Game has the atmosphere, sound design and art style that compliments this Swapper/limbo-esque game perfectly. Combines a nice pace of puzzle solving with backtracking and somewhat satisfying combat, the combat mechanics could use some work since not once did i fear for my life and the boss was somewhat easy to read and managed to kill him fairly fast and outside of the puzzles the game  didnt really challenge me at all, overall i highly recommend playing this if you're into dark sci fi adventure games, specially if its available for sale.

Unfortunately one of the first things that struck me about this game was the erratic mouse control - it takes a while to get used to and is not very smooth. You need to hold down right mouse in order to look around and interact with objects and aim your gun (once you obtain a working weapon), but you cannot see what direction the mouse is facing until you activate it. It makes controlling Arid, the combat suit AI protagonist, unnecessarily difficult as she (it has a female voice) flips directions. Additionally, lining up just right to interact with objects is frustrating.

That aside, this game had me playing until the very end in one hit (maybe a tea break or two, to ponder what on earth [space] I had to do next). Arid's objective from the start is clear: ensure the safety of her human occupant. In exploring to find a means to provide medical attention she finds herself in a run down, android re-purposing facility and you must solve a range of seemingly simple problems and defend yourself (i.e. your human occupant) against hostile security droids to progress. The environment is dark and ominous; you always feel like you are being watched and that there is danger around the corner; it seems a bit of a cross between 'Limbo' and 'The Swapper', but lacking in the awe inspiring backgrounds featured in the latter (which I also just finished playing, so I suppose I was expecting more beauty in the environment of this side scroller).

This game isn't about environmental beauty however. Everything about the story is intriguing, and the environment is also a core part of that. As is hinted in the trailer this game deals with what it is to be an artificial intelligence, and it does so very, very well. The narrative isn't solely told through dialogue: your actions and self-assessments; other characters and their actions and assessments (it becomes clear that this story isn't just about Arid and her human occupant); environment; menus; voice acting and music... it all comes together magnificently and in the end leaves you wanting for more.

So if you enjoy solving puzzles, are interested in science fiction action and philosophy and enjoy some sick twisted humour (did I mention this game has some pretty neat jokes too?), this game is for you. Definitely recommend it!

First episode of a nice hybrid adventure-platformer. The concept itself is wonderful (if ultimately a little obvious) and I do hope they finish the series, as the story is pretty interesting. The controls (I played with xbox gamepad) are bad, particularly aiming, and the basic action of the game (interact with something) seems to take twice as many steps as it should. There are a few other things that seem unpolished, like the display of text when you inspect something. On the other hand, the graphic style is hauntingly good, very reminiscent of The Swapper (that game is nearly without flaw so I think you should prioritize it), and the character animations were excellent as well. The voice acting was great, although some conceits meant that the dialog goes pretty slowly, which made me end up skipping some and just reading. Puzzles were good; I finished without any external hints and most of them made sense. The game was more linear and neat" than I prefer. Overall the Fall presents an intriguing plot backed by interesting characters, voiceovers and an excellent art-style. The game is mared by an interaction and combat system that takes some practice to master and would be aided by a simple controls layout in the menu or on the developers website. Finding online guides or tutorials for some of the simple yet frustrating problems within the game was difficult but a full walkthrough is available on youtube for when players are stuck.

Ultimately, many of the more interesting plots explored in the Fall are never fully explained, such as the caretaker's 'use' of crucifixes and the teasing of A.R.I.D's potential abilities in the distinctly crafted unlock menu. As such I keenly await the release of the next instalment of the Fall mostly to see where the story will go after the ending's twist and because despite its flaws the Fall has hooked me into its dystopian robotic universe. Where are the humans?

Best of luck to the developer.

I would HIGHLY recommend this relatively short game if you enjoyed Limbo or Primordia.

reviewText:
For the TL;DR's

- Short
- Supposedly has 3 parts. 2 and 3 are nowhere to be found.
- Graphics arent bad, but some of the animations leave you disappointed.
- You may need a guide for 1 or 2 parts.
+ Worth buying on sale
+ Great story

Overall, I think this is a game worth buying, but only on sale.
This is the best story I've experienced in a long time. The combat is simple but technical. Hopefully HL3 will be coming soon.

This game is good. Great, even.

You play as the AI of a combat suit.
You have crash landed on an abandoned planet. The person inhabiting your suit is not responding and likely gravely wounded.
You take control of his body and have to get him some medical attention.

Most games that toy with the idea of player agency and free will in a system where there usually is only one right path do it in the form of a plot twist. Would you kindly! Everything you've done has been controlled by an outside force!
In this game, though, the fact that you have no free will is stated upfront. You are a computer program guided by three principles: Protect your pilot, follow orders and don't misrepresent reality. As in many stories where an AI is governed by such laws, they clash: Protecting your pilot means defying orders, breaking protocol, outsmarting other AIs.

The beauty of this game is that story and gameplay go so well together.
The story is about an AI that explores the boundaries of its programming.
The gameplay is a 2D puzzle platformer where most of the puzzles involve outsmarting protocols and following the letter, not the spirit of a rule.

That's all well and good, but most prospective buyers will ask three questions: Is it fun? Does it look good? Does it sound good?

Well, yes, yes and yes.

As I wrote above, the game is a 2D puzzle platformer with cover-based shooting segments. These shooty bits" feel a bit tacked-on in the beginning
date: but become exciting and relevant towards the end. The puzzles strike a fine balance between being reasonably clever while still being rather common-sense. Giving an example would spoil one of the many cool puzzles
recommended: but if your first instinct when encountering a giant path-blocking spider is to shoot it
hoursPlayed: you're going to be fine. The only criticism I can think of here is the fact that some parts are a bit over-reliant on checking every part of the floor and the ceiling.\n\nThe visuals are gorgeous
voteText: especially considering the game was made on a budget. You won't find cutting-edge graphics here
helpfulPercent: but the colors and the lighting really sell the mood here. Heck
votesHelpful:
just look at the screenshots. The animations are fluid and beautiful to look at.

One of the best parts of the game is the writing in combination with the voice acting.
Most of the dialogues take on a rather creepy and monotone tone
votesTotal: because AIs sound creepy and monotone
votesFunny: but the occasional funny or touching line keep it from being boring. The characters are as well-rounded as you could possibly expect from machines that have to rigidly follow rules in everything they do. The written notes are believable and have exactly the right length to convey information and tone without being so long that you're likely to skip over them.\n\nI sincerely recommend checking out this game and I look forward to the next installment of the series."

reviewText: This one is a bit of a mixed bag, i found the premise and characters engaging enough that I wanted to see it through to the end but the puzzles and combat was a bit of a grind and the ending was fairly predictable. really hope they make another, definitely worth the price in my opinion 7/10

I'm going to go ahead and boldly say this is one of the best games I have ever played. I am so glad for the developers to announce they're working on a second episode, because not to continue the story where this ends would be criminal.

Very simple control scheme and combat mechanics (I used keyboard & mouse), but enough to be involving at all times. There is a heavy puzzle element to it, and in a couple of places I was stumped and had to do a pretty lengthy search for solutions, but in the end you realise it is fairly common sensical.

Voice-acting is intense as well as the storyline (which is quite innovative), this game really drew an emotionial response from me.
The level design is also top drawer, dark and moody, and unsettling in places.

Couldn't recommend this game higher!
Interesting concept but the puzzles alternate from laboriously simplistic to DOTT illogical. Quite short too despite the backtracking and slow movement pace. I'd only recommend it if it was on sale.

I like the aesthetic, the quasi-metroidvania style level design, and all these robots and AI. What I don't like is how some of the puzzles have components easily missed (interactables aren't highlighted unless you look directly at the thing in question, which might be hard when everything is a silhouette), and the entire game generally feels like the teaser/demo for something bigger. As it is, it's brutally short.\n\nWorth buying, but expect a short (but fun, I guess) bang for your buck, so consider it if it's on special.

Great game. This is an indie game done right. Exceptional atmosphere and enviroment, and an impressive, fresh, combat system. A breath of fresh air for the 2D sidescroller genre. A story so good, I cant wait for part 2!

Fantastic action/adventure game! It's got all the right elements: awesome mysterious/creepy story, morbid humour, great style, perfect voice acting, ... The puzzle elements were just hard enough. highly recommended for anyone looking for an utterly absorbing  adventure game: this is it!

Interesting puzzles. Manages to dodge the incredibly contrived solutions that often plague adventure games. The atmosphere is fantastic, very reminiscent of Portal, or perhaps more relevantly, I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream.\n\nIt is short, but that didn't really bother me.

I found this game very good and definitly recommend it. Although bugs are possible I did not run into many while playing. It takes roughly five hours to complete the story but Boy, Is it well written. The story is Interesting,Mysterious and creepy all binded into one. But the voice acting is incredible.I would definitly recommend this to anyone looking for a singleplayer sidescroller,Shooter,Story,Horror game and has 10 Dollars to spare.

Having just finished episode 1, I absolutely want more!

Admittedly, I got a little frustrated in the middle of the episode as I was stuck on a puzzle, but if anything that only enhances how I look back on The Fall. It tells me that it's an exceptionally intelligent game, with some real head scratchers of puzzles. The puzzles were pretty darn challenging for me, but what really stood out to me was the story telling. The story is compelling to follow, and despite my hopeless frustration in solving a couple of the puzzles, the allure of exploring the story further kept me coming back. Eventually, I found a walkthrough to get me past the more horrid puzzles, but I am proud to say I solved most of it myself (so far!).

The story telling and the philosophical angles taken certainly deserve merit. The dialogue is deliberate, thoughtful, at times poignant, and always serves to further the story. I really enjoyed the elements of deadpan humour (what would you expect from a game about artifical intelligence?) in The Fall. There were moments where I found myself laughing out loud, which certainly added variety to the method of story progression.

The art style and environment are also well done, with a persistent gloomy atmosphere, much in line with the overall feel of the game. The environment also plays a role in conveying the story, through simple observations from your character (named A.R.I.D). The controls took a little getting used to, but they weren't anything inhibitive. They were certainly different to anything I remember playing before, but once you're in the swing of things they end up being pretty intuitive. Overall, the game plays smoothly, looks good and above all else succeeds in telling it's story; You just need to work for it, is all.

amazing storytelling, great voice-acting, and lovely, dark atmosphere\n\ntoo bad this game is very, very short, took me something like 3 hours to complete it, I just hope they're gonna release a (possibly free) update in the future

2D Dead Space minus gore. The atmosphere is fantastic. The story is quite original, keeps you on your toes. Combat is kinda lame, but meh. Doesn't detract from the very clever design choices in this game. I am so glad I went on a selling spree on the Market to get it when it was 4.99 on the Summer Sale.

What Not To Look For:
X a highly polished combat system
X hints every step of the way
X a game to keep you hooked for 100 hours
X smooth and fluid controls

What To Look Forward To:
+ a fantastic story exploring AI capabilties
+ a wonderful adventure style game in the vein of I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream
+ flawless, professional sounding voice acting
+ an amazing atmosphere lit primarily by screens and robot lights

It's honestly a very short game, so I suggest you wait until it's on sale, but over all The Fall is a great game, like reading a classic Isacc Asimov novel. Well, if Isacc Asimov played Dead Space, anyway.

The Pros

An immersive story where you're constantly trying to piece together what happened and you WANT to know what happened.

Gameplay mechanics that are woven into the story and result in very interesting concepts down the road

A cast of characters that, while limited, are very well characterized and memorable.

Puzzles that 90% of the time are tricky to figure out, but satisfying when you eventually do.

Excellent audio.

A very original concept that the game capitalizes on with flying colors.

A simple plot that goes in directions that I was not expecting and leaves me eager for the next chapter.

A few rather humerous achivements.

Neutral.

The game's run time is rather short with me clocking in at four hours, after spending a fair amount of time stuck on some puzzles, but the low price evens this out.

Cons

Combat is rather clunky.  Most of the time it is servicable but several fights towards the end proved to be very irratable.

While 90% of the puzzles are tricky but managable, the other 10% fall into the pit of bizare point and click adventure game logic where the solution seems rather arbitrary.

The next one isn't out yet.

Conclusion

A short and tight story with inovative ideas that serve the story instead of just being innovation for the sake of innovation, a masterfully written story with clever puzzle solving, with the flaws in a few annoying puzzles and clunky combat only taking away a little from the overall experience.  All the frustrations I had with the final fights were instantly swept away by the story's brilliant conclusion.

This game is very much worth a purchase and I eagerly await the next game.  I hope that the few flaws that there are will be fixed in the sequel, but merely being just as good as this one will be enough to get a purchase from me.

Excepting its length, The Fall is a great experience. Generally good writing, lovely sound (though it got annoying when you had to go through the same terminal multiple times), decent pacing, and an excellent look and feel overall were all fun, refreshing, and well executed.\n\nHowever, the game takes 3-4 hours to complete, with no indication of whether you've purchased the next segments by purchasing the first. It's still more entertainment time per dollar than a movie, but less than most video games.
About 3-4 hours long but sweet. I think the story was well done and feels like there could be a lot more, mayber further down the road. I hope they continue in this universe.

Great game, thought provoking.

Can't wait for the sequel.

But a word of warning. It does require patiance.
Amazing

The Fall is a sci-fi thriller that has a fresh take on Asimov's law of robotics. The game's atmosphere is well thought out with well paced music, well written character design, and the combat is spaced far enough not to get dull and repetitive. I still recommend keeping a Steam walkthrough guide open in the background, should you run into a snag. There were a few puzzles that got me stuck, not due to their difficulty, but rather due to their obscurity on how to approach the problem.\n\nThe game took me around two and half hours to clear, so The Fall might not be the best time-to-money investment there is, but the title is still well worth the buy in my opinion.

Bottom line, this is a fantastic game. A true surprise, I didn't know what to expect but all of my preconceptions were completely wrong. The thing that sets this game apart is it's story and writing. There isn't anything new as far as game play goes but the story is great. It is very short though, even for an episodic game but the puzzles help to extend the rather short story.

If you are looking for something different, something that will engage your imagination then this game is for you. If you want the next action packed, epic sidescroller you might want to pass. There is action but it's spread out and balanced to not take away from the story.

Can't wait for the next one.
the fall is rather short and still has a few bugs to work out (at least on PC) but it is definitly an awesome game that i don't regret buying.

By far my favorite game at the moment. The Fall combines classic sidescrolling adventure you can find in Super Mario Brothers and Mega Man titles with difficult puzzle solving elements, reminiscent of Portal 2, but better. Action elements like firefights add wonderful moments of hiding behind cover or cloaking in with your surroundings. A dash of horror makes this game slightly creepy, but just enough so. Interactive conversations that are similar to those in The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim add a bit of character to your  gameplay. Artwork that looks like it came from a strange LIMBO sequel combined with amazing voice-acting and music makes the game immensely immersive. 10/10.
fantastic game, Impressive story that makes the AI character believeable. not many indy games have left me wanting for more.

Pretty short but increidibly interesting. Awesome character development with the protagonist and the antagonist is a different but fantastic villain. A bit pricey for how short it is though. The atmosphere provides enough creepy aura to make the game have that horror game feel without actually being a horror game. The puzzles are pretty difficult at some points and have that where do I go what do I do" helpless feeling which might be my only negative view of the game. However figuring out the puzzles after that frustration factor sets in is incredibly rewarding and makes you feel good about yourself. All in all I'd give it an 8.5/10
date: the only thing docking it points being the length of the game and the mediocre conveyance with the puzzles."

reviewText: If you like puzzles, and the ambiance of deadspace... then this one is for you! Go for it!!! You cant go wrong either way, because this will fund the trilogy that this will be apart of :)
Extremely nice setting, scenery and really fascinating plot!
Absolutely gripping and I felt the caretaker was one of the most meaningful boss fights ive had in a while, can't wait for the countinuation

First thing to say: this is not a Metroidvania in any sense of the term. The combat can be annoying at times, and some of the puzzles are a bit overly obtuse, but if you like adventure games that have a little bit of combat to them, this is a great one.

The atmosphere is very good and reminds me much of some of the best adventure games of the past. Surprisingly great voice acting and a well-contrived plot round out a good experience that is just about the right length.

The to be continued" at the end is a bit odd and it's not clear what that would be. Nor are some of the greater mysteries of the setting explained fully. But if you like atmospheric adventure
date: you'll enjoy it while it lasts."

reviewText: Great little puzzler with an eerie vibe, intriguing story and fast paced action sequences. All for $10!
One of the best sci-fi stories I've played / watched / listened to.  Really captivating and great art style.  The puzzles are really challenging at times, but its worth it to keep at them.

I went in with no expectations, but from a brief glimpse, I never expected to step into such a realised and interesting universe, nor did I expect to have my morals challenged in the process. ARID and her counterparts are surprisingly genuine, as well as supported by fantastic voice performances. This is not your typical android science fiction story, and the end result is utterly compelling. The unique blend of genres works incredibly well, without ever feeling as if it’s ever imitating the creator’s source of inspiration. There is an excellent balance between player exploration and tactical shooting; both of which are fueled by creative puzzles that think outside the box. There are still a few rough edges to iron out, but as this is the first game in a trilogy, I think an incredible foundation has been laid. The conclusion, will, without a doubt, have you on the edge of your seat. If you only buy one game this steam sale, make sure it’s The Fall.\n\nIf you would like to read my full review, you can find it here: http://gamecloud.net.au/review/the-fall
Beautiful game. Some of the puzzles were Monkey Island-esque as you'll use non-logical solutions. Really great storyline, I got goosebumps several times. Looking forward to the next installment!

a great game that takes elements from mertoid adventure games and PC-only games where you need to think really hard if you want to progress.Simply amazing and pretty close to masterpeacial in my opinion
Very innovative. Has a nice balance of clever scripting and dark atmosphere.

Fantastic atmosphere
Well told sci-fi story
Clever puzzles that aren't too difficult but do require thinking
Recommended.
A beautiful game with a compelling narrative that concludes perfectly. I am looking forward to the next chapter in this story. Nom Nom Nom.
It was a very well crafted game i hope that the next chapter will be released.

Highly recommended: Some of the puzzles require old-school adventure game nonlinear thinking, but it's nothing completely obscure and nonsensical.  If you're diligent, you'll find the solutions.

But it's the story that will rock you, so long as you like dystopian cyberpunk post-apocalyptic type tales.

Somehow, a simple combat suit AI is one of my favorite characters.  I am going to lose my mind if I have to wait too long for the rest of the trilogy.

This was a pretty good mind bender of a game. a lot of the puzzles were genuinely challenging in that you have to get on the character's level of thinking to really understand what to do in some situations. I was pretty sad it was so short and ended on a cliffhanger, and I really wish I'd gotten to know more about the caretaker, but all in all I'm more than eager to get the next episode when it comes out.
Waited a long time for a game from the past. Great gameplay packed in a perfect world. I can recommend it in any way.
Incredible.
Wow! What a story! Gameplay is mostly solid. Can't wait for the sequel.
A really atmospheric adventure game with a killer setting and premise.  Fully recommend.

The puzzles and story are interesting and often surprising.  You may need to use event triggers or objects in multiple ways to solve puzzles.   The interface and combat" are clunky but you will eventually get used to it.     All in all

reviewText: Its a fun and engaging game, can't wait  for the other two parts

I definitly agree that this game was very short and I dont know if I would ahve paid for it at ten bucks but while it was on sale for 5 buck it was definitly worth every dollar. Very simple plot but very enjoyable all the way to the end!
They said I was malfunctioning, I said they were irrelevant. 5 stars.
Rather short, but a fun and interesting story.  Worth a buy if it's on sale.

For a game that still needs some polish (I found some of the puzzles to be a little abstract, others you had to look high and low to find things) this was an IMPRESSIVE game story-wise. When you sit and think about the things that are going on, you find a pretty engaging discussion about rigid rules and their worth, and very early in the game, despite being tasked to keep the pilot inside your suit alive, you have to place him in danger in order to pass through some puzzles. So are you fulilling your directives? or abandoning them?

All in all, I'm happy I got this on sale for $5 and I'm looking forward to picking up the next installment and seeing what happens.

Bottom line: Needs some polish with the interface and the puzzles, but is awesome enough to stand on it's own as the start of a great series.

My first impression was that game would be something like limbo(action game) or swapper(puzzle game). It's strange that developers decided to make a hybrid between point&click and shooter. It feels like they prototyped guns and decided to leave them in because it was too much work to finish the proper action game. As a result the game features unique UI for adventure game. It was a real pain to use. Upgrade screen also seems like unfinished metroidvania idea. Shooting does not work - it's not fun. It's easy and just serves as action filler between proper adventure sections.
Adventure component works reasonably well. I think I get the main narrative point about breaking the rules.
Visuals and voice acting are really good.
I can only recommend this game to people who want to better understand how hard it is to design a game outside of existing genre.
Very well designed, great thinking puzzels, 10/10
Good artwork, dark and spooky.  Puzzles are somewhat tricky, but if you do not follow a specific order in completing tasks, it works out.  Very short, but I got it on sale, still recommend.

Amazing Game, Great story, loved it. Needs a sequel badly.\n\nThat being said, it has a very short playthrough time, 3 hours tops. This being an indie game is the only reason I would spend $10 on it, I got it durring summer sale when it was 50% off. In essense, it needs more content to merit $10. But I am looking forward to it's sequels and will buy them. Must Buy and Must Play for any story lovers.
A really well done game, there are a few bugs with the save/load though so if you can, play it in one session.  Takes about 4 hours.
Well, for now I ahve Ubuntu 14.04 LTS, and the intro video makes crash to desktop. If I skip intro, game starts. Have not tried toplay longer yet. Will see.
THAT PLOT TWIST THO!

This game is honestly one of the most well writen games I've played. The ending is completely unexpected, and makes me ask so many questions that I can't wait for the next in the trilogy to come out (even though as I write this reveiw I know it will be almost a year before the next game.)! The game is very short, but that is to be expected, it is just episode one of the game, and it was made by an independent developer. While I would have liked there to have been more of the story to play through (damn this game was awesome), I will be buying the next games in the series to figure out what happens to what is now my favorite AI (Yes, I like her more then cortana.).

Good Game with a lot of atmosphere and a great story.
The controls are kind of stiff and need some getting used to.  Sometimes the things your can interact with are hard to find or see, because they are in some strange edges of the screen. So you might find yourself backtracking a lot in this game to find the one thing to help you progress. But nothing too bad. The action sequences are exciting and make a nice change without destroying the atmosphere.

I really recommend it, BUT it is really short (about three to four hours). In the description it says, that this is just the first game in a trilogy, but it still was very short on its own.  For such a short play time, it was overpriced. I definitely would wait for a sale.
Fantastic little adventure game with a great story and characters. I can't wait for the second episode, really want to know where the story is going.

A quick and compelling adventure game in the style and atmosphere of games like: The Swapper, Limbo, Deadlight, and other 2.5D sidescrolling adventures with a mix of combat and puzzles. Definitely worth the buy, especially since there are plans for a next episode. (sequel/DLC?)

Don't let the short play time of this game push you away from it. After all, what was Portal?\nWhile the controls and some of the puzzles are not very intuitive, it took me back to my days of playing Abuse. I really enjoyed the story, the characters, and the setting. I hope very much to see more of ARID in the future, and THANK YOU Over The Moon for showing that you don't need pixel graphics to make a 2d action/adventure game (pixel graphics have always been my beef with most independant games, it feels like a giant cop out).\nAs for the 'steep price' for this game, I hardly call the price of a Something Awful forum account a steep price. This game was worth my 10bux and I'll gladly buy the foreshadowed next installment.
Just bought this, the style of this game takes me back to older console days. This is like the game that you always wanted that was never released. Great Sci-Fi/Suspense puzzle game.
Fairly interesting take on the adventure game formula. Some of the puzzles felt a bit obtuse, but the story kept me hanging around.

Aesthetically, I argue this is one of the most awesome games on Steam. The environments and story are immersive. The puzzles are challenging, the mechanics work well enough. Definitely worth a playthrough. It's apparently a single chapter of a larger story, so fairly short, but with a probability of continuation in the future.

As Indie goes, this is one of the better games out there. Inexpensive, well-written and well-designed. However, it was rather short and ended on a to-be-continued note. I hope there will be more episode releases soon.
Great game. Fun. Had puzzly stuff and combat which was really good fun. Cannot wait for secound one.
Great game with superb ending.

reviewText: Atmospheric, minimal, superbly written. It sounds like a Metroidvania going in, but ends up being more of an adventure game a la Monkey Island. There's also some shooting/stealth mechanics, but they're very barebones. The puzzles and the story are the draw here, and they're great.

This game had me hooked from start to finish. It's not very long and there are definitely some small issues I have with it but I give alot of credit to this first time developer because he dished out what I would consider to be a top shelf game.

Gameplay is similar to any side scroller shooter you have encountered but the dev adds observation points that add a huge amount of atmosphere and story to this little game.

If I had one complaint it's that some of the puzzles will get you stuck if you happen to miss a single piece to the puzzle. I spent 45 minutes running through every level trying to find a cup once because I missed it in a pretty obvious place! Yes it was probably my fault but it would be nice if there was some sort of help or multiple ways to finish a puzzle in case this happens to someone else. I'm sure the developer will figure something out to prevent slowdowns.

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone, even at the $10 price point. The game took me around six hours to complete. I've bought games for $60 that took less time and were far less entertaining. Cheers!

this game makes you think.  this game makes you feel.  this game forces you to push imaginative boundaries and begs you to keep playing. i found myself attatched to ARID,  and wanted nothing more than to help her save her injured pilot...everyone should play this game.  i can't wait to find out what happens next.

The Fall is a breath of fresh (or rather, stale and decaying) air.  There are no groundbreaking gameplay mechanics, but its strenght lies in its beautifully dark story.  Some of the puzzles are a bit elaborate and boil down to excessive trial and error, or in my case a couple 'please-help-me-internet' moments.  That aside, The Fall doesn't overstay its welcome and in the end it left me hoping for more solid game offerings from Over The Moon.

If you like science fiction, a storyline that isn't exposition but deals with great philosophy, and has action elements with an out-of-the-box puzzle focus, this game is worth every resource. At two dollars per hour of average gameplay, this indie game was one of my first purchases and still holds a special place in my mind.  The only downfall I can possibly consider is the minimalism in the art. 'The Fall' wasn't glorious to look at, but it seemed fitting for the game.\n\nA Steam favorite, and I anxiously await the sequel(s).
Really good puzzle game with exciting combat. Recommended

Not a bad idea at all.
Great story beats that keep you intrigued until the end with better than average story telling and voice acting. It was a tight but well thought out game with a level design that made sense given the environment.

Shoot outs are rather basic and don;t add a great deal apart from to break the pace a little and I got frustrated by not seeing certain aspects simply from choices that I was unaware were going to lock me out of experiencing certain things or learning more story details.

None the less it is decent for the money paid and impressive work for largely one guy.

Played on windows with mouse and keyboard, I had no issues with the controls, and one glitch after a cutscene where my character was flung off screen and the camera didn't follow.

+Interesting, well executed story.

Keeping in mind that this is only part 1 of 3, this game is definitely worth playing, the story and the atmosphere will keep you engrossed until the very end. Pick it up if you're looking for a great story but don't have a ton of time to do needless junk. Pick it up regardless if it goes on sale, you won't regret it.

To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it far too often made reviews too long to submit (an unfortunate consequence of my sometimes very verbose method of writing), I've instead decided to leave the header on my Backloggery.

Gameplay: I picked up The Fall when it was on sale, and if you're anything like me, you no doubt will have picked this game up based solely on the trailer. While this trailer does somewhat sell up the game, it is by no means a disappointment. We'll talk more about the trailer in the story section, though. The gameplay of The Fall is one of a rather esoteric genre known as the Cinematic Platformer. Two sterling examples of this kind of gameplay are Another World/Out of this World and Flashback (the old one). However, if you remember particularly frustrating moments from the former example; do not worry. This game has no absurdly precise platforming in it. Truth be told, this game doesn't have much platforming at all, but that's perfectly fine; it doesn't need it.

Rather, the core of the gameplay plays more like a traditional point-and-click adventure game in which you will sometimes be able to cleverly figure out the puzzle and other times just spend five or ten minutes just rubbing objects on other objects to create success. Yes, this game does have some Sierra logic here and there, much to my dismay. Also, due to how dark the game's presentation is, it is sometimes more challenging to even distinguish what you need to be clicking on. You can only interact with objects by shining the flash light from your gun on said object, so you don't have to worry about accidentally using things over and over again, but considering how dark the game is, it sometimes becomes a task of flailing your light everywhere in a desperate attempt to find something that you can rub against something in your inventory. Yes, the repetition of the word something was intentional in that last sentence.

Much like Another World/Out of this World, there is some element of gunplay. Don't worry, though; your gun has infinite shots, so you won't be screwed over by that. You only really fight one type of enemy throughout the game, but once again; that's not that big of a deal. There are also some abilities that unlock as the game progresses, but not all of them are available by the end game. I was confused by this until I found out that this game was meant to be the first in a series. Considering that, it is in a way no surprise that the game's platforming and combat felt inconsequential at times.

Overall, the gameplay isn't the most brilliant aspect of this game. The puzzles can be alright at times but othertimes completely obtuse; the platforming and gunplay are rather insiginificant at times; however, they do their job to keep this game from just being another walking simulator. 7/10.

Story: I mentioned that I'd be talking about the trailer here, so I most definitely will be. The Conform" trailer represents this game as being mainly about an AI's crisis of identity as it gradually gains more and more of a simulacrum of what we humans would call a true consciousness. While this is a core theme of the game
date: there is more to it than that. There aren't many charcters in this game; in fact
recommended: there's really only three characters including the enigmatic Caretaker. They all do their job serving the plot and the dialogue is really the main presentation vehicle of the themes. Just the way it should be in my opinion. I don't want to spoil too much
voteText: but just know that this game has some very excellent writing behind it
